author: (Associated Press)
title: Justice Dept. offers opinion backing legality of Whitaker's appointment
description: The state of Maryland has challenged Whitaker’s appointment.
content: Matthew Whitaker was previously chief of staff to now-ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions a job that didnt require Senate confirmation. | Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images WASHINGTON The Justice Department has issued an internal legal opinion supporting the leg… [+942 chars]
fulltext:
Matthew Whitaker was previously chief of staff to now-ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions — a job that didn’t require Senate confirmation. | Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images Legal DOJ defends Trump’s acting A.G. appointment in memo The 20-page DOJ memo leans heavily on historical precedent to argue that Trump was well within his constitutional and legal bounds.

A new Justice Department analysis released Wednesday backs up President Donald Trump’s appointment last week of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker despite a growing political and legal backlash.

The 20-page DOJ memo — addressed to top White House attorney Emmet Flood — leans heavily on historical precedent to argue that Trump was well within his constitutional and legal bounds to elevate Whitaker over other senior Justice officials as the temporary replacement for ousted Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Story Continued Below

Whitaker, a former federal prosecutor who was working as Sessions’ chief of staff before getting the promotion to become the nation’s top law enforcement official, has already drawn lawsuits and congressional scrutiny over his conflicts of interest and because he hasn’t been confirmed for any current Justice position.

But Steven Engel, the head of DOJ’s Office of Legal Counsel, argued in the new memo that the Justice Department has previously leaned on the same law Trump used — the Vacancies Reform Act — to depart from its own succession plans.

In addition, Engel pushed back against suggestions Trump violated the Constitution’s Appointments Clause by noting that someone who performs the duties in a temporary capacity doesn’t have to go through the Senate confirmation process.

“As all three branches of government have long recognized, the President may designate an acting official to perform the duties of a vacant principal office, including a Cabinet office, even when the acting official has not been confirmed by the Senate,” wrote Engel.

Drawing on U.S. history, Engel explained that presidents have had the legal right to put non-Senate confirmed officials into government positions going as far back as 1792. That includes more than 160 appointments before 1860 for positions that included secretaries of State, Treasury, War, Navy and Interior.

DOJ also found an example from 1866 when a non-Senate confirmed assistant attorney general took over as acting attorney general.

“Mr. Whitaker’s designation is no more constitutionally problematic than countless similar presidential orders dating back over 200 years,” Engel wrote.

While much of the Justice Department memo is devoted to the long history of similar appointments, the Supreme Court has sometimes scoffed at such arguments when the justices conclude that such practices fly in the face of the Constitution.

In 2012, the Justice Department issued a similar legal opinion justifying three of President Barack Obama's appointments to the National Labor Relations Board. And in 2014, the justices unanimously ruled those appointments unconstitutional. However, they appeared divided on how much deference to give to tradition in such disputes.

Complaints about Whitaker have only grown since Trump last week tapped Whitaker the day after the November mid-term elections where Democrats won control of the House. Already, the state of Maryland has filed a motion Tuesday in federal court seeking to overturn the Whitaker appointment. Incoming House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has said Whitaker would be his first witness when Democrats take control of the lower chamber in January.

In promoting Whitaker, Trump has also sparked an uproar because of his past criticism of special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation examining any potential conspiracy between Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign and Russia.

Whitaker in his new role has taken over supervising duties of Mueller’s work from Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general who was in charge of the special counsel because Sessions had previously recused himself from the topic.

DOJ initially said Whitaker had no plans to back away from overseeing Mueller, but on Monday it signaled the acting attorney general was consulting with senior DOJ ethics officials and reopened the possibility he could recuse himself.

Josh Gerstein contributed to this report.

author: Burgess Everett
title: Schumer re-elected to lead Senate Democrats
description: The Senate leadership is falling into place.
content: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer was first elected to the Senate in 1998. | AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer were re-elected by voice vote to lead their respective parties on Wednesday, according to sources familiar with the … [+714 chars]
fulltext:
Sen. Joni Ernst's rise marks the first time in eight years a woman has joined the Senate GOP leadership. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Congress Ernst joins GOP Senate leadership Sens. Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer were also re-elected to lead their respective parties.

Sen. Joni Ernst of Iowa on Wednesday beat Nebraska's Deb Fischer to win the Republican Senate Conference vice chairmanship, the only contested leadership race in a Senate that will return the bulk of the parties' leaders.

Ernst's win over Fischer marks the first time in eight years a woman is in the Senate GOP leadership. Senators said they were not provided with a vote total, and Fischer quickly moved on and told reporters she's going to continue to be "very active" in the caucus' work. Ernst, who is up for reelection in 2020 and is expected to face a credible Democratic challenge, said she will focus on sharing the GOP's record of "prosperity" with her constituents while in Washington.

Story Continued Below

Sens. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) were reelected by voice vote to lead their respective parties, according to sources familiar with the decisions.

Several other significant but expected moves took place in the GOP caucus, mostly involving promotions for existing Senate leaders. Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) will now be party whip, Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.) will be the conference chairman, the No. 3 job, and Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) will be the Republican Policy chairman. Senate President Pro Tempore Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) is retiring and will be replaced in the role by Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) as the most senior GOP senator and in the line of presidential succession.

And Sen. Todd Young (R-Ind.) will chair the National Republican Senatorial Committee for the next cycle, working to protect Ernst and outgoing NRSC Chairman Cory Gardner of Colorado, among other vulnerable senators. On the Democratic side, Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto (D-Nev.) has spoken to Schumer about chairing the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, but no final decision has been made, according to multiple Democratic sources.

McConnell's reelection makes him the GOP leader for his seventh term. Schumer will begin his second term as minority leader next year.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201811/2910/1155968404_5940956678001_5940956253001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true

No one opposed Schumer vocally, including Sen.-elect Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, who had said during her campaign she would not support Schumer, according to two senators. Those senators said they did not hear anyone object to Schumer’s nomination.

“Had there been a challenger for minority leader, I would have considered new leadership and a fresh perspective,” Sinema said in a statement. “I will continue to put Arizona over party.”

Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn of Texas, who is term-limited, is leaving the elected leadership but will still be a "counsel" to McConnell. Fischer is currently a counsel but said she was unsure whether she will stay in that role in the next Congress.

The sprawling Democratic leadership team does not have term limits like the GOP and will remain unchanged, other than at the DSCC position. The top rungs of the team will include: Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Assistant Democratic Leader Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and Democratic Policy and Communications Committee Chairman Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.). Other members of the leadership team are Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Mark Warner (D-Va.), Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.), Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.).

Marianne Levine contributed to this report.

author: coprysko@politico.com (Caitlin Oprysko)
title: Flake, Coons call troop deployments to the border a 'stunt'
description: Flake noted that the troops in Arizona had actually been deployed almost 100 miles from the border itself.
content: Sen. Chris Coons (R), who sits on the Judiciary Committee with Sen. Jeff Flake, said that he agreed with the retiring Arizona lawmaker about the unnecessary deployment of troops. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Sen. Jeff Flake on Wednesday called President Donald Tr… [+2370 chars]
fulltext:
Sen. Chris Coons (right), who sits on the Judiciary Committee with Sen. Jeff Flake, said he agreed with the retiring Arizona lawmaker about the unnecessary deployment of troops. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Immigration Flake, Coons call troop deployments to the border a 'stunt'

Sen. Jeff Flake on Wednesday called President Donald Trump's decision to deploy U.S. troops along the U.S.-Mexico border a "stunt," noting that the troops in his home state of Arizona had actually been deployed almost 100 miles from the border itself.

“I think it's unfortunate that we have soldiers there, and frankly in Arizona they are stationed in Tucson about 90 miles from the border. So they are not forward deployed actually on the border,” the outgoing Republican said on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.” “So I think you can't call it anything but a stunt here, and it's unfortunate that they are going to be away from family during the holidays coming up, and we just don't know what really for.”

Story Continued Below

Critics of the Trump administration have accused the president of using military resources as political chess pieces, along with heated rhetoric, in the lead-up to last week's midterm elections in an effort to stir concern over caravans of asylum-seeking migrants headed for the U.S. as a dangerous “invasion.”

Trump railed against the migrants repeatedly in the final days of the campaign, but has fallen mostly silent on the issue since Election Day, save for an executive order last week to block the migrants from seeking asylum if they are caught crossing the border illegally.

Morning Shift newsletter Get the latest on employment and immigration, every weekday morning — in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Flake, an outspoken critic of the president who decided not to run for reelection because of his disagreements with Trump, said Wednesday that he thought the caravan was nothing that couldn’t be handled by “civilians that we have there in terms of border patrol and others.”

He added that he wasn’t sure he could offer words of affirmation to troops discouraged by their deployment to the southern border.

“I don't know what I could tell them other than we shouldn't be doing this,” he said. “This wasn’t an issue that Congress was involved in. It was an executive decision.”

Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.), who sits on the Judiciary Committee with Flake and joined him on "Morning Joe," said he agreed with the retiring Arizona lawmaker.

“I would have to look them in the eye and say thank you for your service and I regret that our president is using you as a political stunt,” Coons said.

title: Democracy for America installs first female chief executive
description: The appointment represents a generational shift as younger, nonwhite voters and candidates put their mark on progressive politics nationwide.
content: Yvette Simpson, a former Cincinnati councilwoman, will become chief executive of Democracy for America next year. She is the first woman of color to hold an executive leadership role at the organization,. | John Minchillo/AP Photo The progressive political ac… [+2787 chars]
fulltext:
Yvette Simpson, a former Cincinnati councilwoman, will become chief executive of Democracy for America next year. She is the first woman of color to hold an executive leadership role at the organization,. | John Minchillo/AP Photo Elections Democracy for America installs first female chief executive

The progressive political action committee Democracy for America is appointing its first female chief executive as it reorganizes ahead of the 2020 presidential campaign, while Jim Dean will step down from his role as chair.

Yvette Simpson, a former Cincinnati councilwoman, will become chief executive Jan. 1, the first woman of color to hold an executive leadership role at the organization, the group said.

Story Continued Below

The appointment represents a generational shift for DFA, as younger, nonwhite voters and candidates put their mark on progressive politics nationwide. DFA boasts more than 1 million members and was an instrumental supporter of Sen. Bernie Sanders’ failed 2016 presidential campaign.

“After an election year defined by historic firsts and the profound impact women of color played in delivering them, I couldn’t be more excited about Democracy for America’s future with Yvette Simpson as its new Chief Executive,” Dean said in a prepared statement. “Having the opportunity to work closely with the grassroots to help push our country in a more progressive direction has truly been an honor and one of the greatest thrills of my life, but I also know that we won’t be able to achieve the kind of change our country needs if we don’t let a new generation of bold, visionary progressive leaders, like Yvette, lead the way.”

Asked about criticism that progressive groups have failed to reflect diversity, Dean said, “I think this is an important step for us to move beyond that.”

Morning Score newsletter Your guide to the permanent campaign — weekday mornings, in your inbox. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

Founded by Howard Dean following his run for president in 2004, DFA helped lead an unsuccessful movement to draft Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) into the 2016 presidential campaign, then swung its support to Sanders (I-Vt.).

The group also endorsed Minnesota Rep. Keith Ellison in his unsuccessful bid for Democratic National Committee chairman. DFA said it has raised and contributed more than $62 million to progressive candidates nationwide since 2004.

Simpson, who drew outsize attention from progressives in her bid for Cincinnati mayor in 2017, most recently served as DFA’s federal electoral manager, recruiting and supporting candidates in the midterm elections.

With her appointment, Jim Dean will become a special adviser at DFA, a role his brother held through 2016. DFA’s current executive director, Charles Chamberlain, will become chairman.

“DFA has a long history of taking on races that traditionally people don’t, supporting candidates that are brown and black and are progressive,” Simpson said.

For DFA, she said, “The future looks like more of that.”

title: Brady's ready
description: Now it can be told — Acting judiciously
content: Editors Note: This edition of Morning Tax is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Tax subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pros comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy t… [+9982 chars]
fulltext:
Brady's ready

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Tax is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Tax subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

BRADY'S READY: House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady isn't sure how much appetite his colleagues will have for tax legislation during the lame-duck session, but he's ready just in case. The Texas Republican is planning to soon circulate draft legislation to fix the "retail glitch" and other hiccups in the new tax law, along with a tax extenders package, our Aaron Lorenzo reports. It could be House Republicans' last tax hurrah before slipping into the minority next year.

Story Continued Below

Tax pros and those affected by the retail glitch have been waiting for months to see if Republicans would put forward a technical corrections bill for the tax law, H.R. 1 (115). Of course, retailers and restaurant owners consider their problem to be more than just technical. The glitch requires them to write off certain investments over decades, rather than over one year as Republicans intended. Brady said his legislation will include 70 to 80 other alterations to the law, the vast majority of which he characterized as very minor clarifications, Aaron wrote. "Again, we'll see what appetite there is to pass some or the bulk of them before the end of the year," Brady said.

The second piece of legislation includes a group of tax incentives with expiration dates that didn't make it into 2015 legislation that made dozens of other extenders permanent. "We have developed a draft package approach on the temporary measures that we're going to visit with our members about, Ranking Member [Richard] Neal and the Senate as well," Brady told reporters. He's been a longtime advocate of ending the annual extenders ritual, but it never seems to work out.

NOW IT CAN BE TOLD: The incentive packages that states, cities and counties were offering Amazon to host its second headquarters have been largely veiled in secrecy. But the company’s decision to split the HQ, and its 50,000 jobs, between Arlington’s Crystal City and Long Island City in Queens has pulled the veil back a bit. To wit: The state of New York will provide $1.2 billion in tax credits and a $325 million capital grant; the company also plans to apply for up to $1 billion in other incentives through NYC programs, POLITICO New York’s Dana Rubinstein reported. In Virginia, state and county officials will fork over $573 million in cash grants, the Technology team’s Steven Overly reported. Tennessee will provide a $21.7 million tax credit to offset franchise and excise taxes for an "Operations Center of Excellence" in Nashville, the company said in a blog post announcing the deals.

The tax incentive offered by New York will come in the form of a refundable tax credit "calculated as a percentage of the salaries Amazon expects to pay employees over the next 10 years, which equates to $48,000 per job for 25,000 jobs with an average wage of over $150,000," Amazon said. Arlington's cash grant will come from expected growth in revenue from its hotel room tax. The city will also "dedicate an estimated $28 million based on 12% of future property tax revenues earned from an existing Tax Increment Financing (TIF) district for on-site infrastructure and open space" in Crystal City, Amazon said. The company offered no explanation for the wide difference in incentives between the two cities, though it presumably has to do with higher taxes and other expenses in New York City.

While New York and Virginia officials hailed Amazon’s decision as an economic coup for their regions, naysayers came out of the woodwork. “The arrangements have drawn the ire of Amazon critics including incoming Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, whose district neighbors Long Island City,” Steven reported. “‘Amazon is a billion-dollar company,” she tweeted late Monday night. "’The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need MORE investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here.’”

A BIG WEDNESDAY WELCOME to you from the Pro Tax crew. Email: bbecker@politico.com, teckert@politico.com, bfaler@politico.com, alorenzo@politico.com. Twitter: @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brianfaler, @aaronelorenzo,@POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax.

ACTING JUDICIOUSLY: Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) said he has to consult with his colleagues before deciding whether to take the gavel of the Finance Committee or stay on as Judiciary chairman. “Grassley has long said he would make his decision immediately after the midterms, presumably to see who captured the majority,” our Burgess Everett reported. “But now he says he needs more time to talk to GOP senators that will be affected by his decision given the domino effect Grassley will produce either way.” Grassley told reporters that he “forgot that I have an obligation” to see what his fellow Republican senators think.

Judiciary may offer more razzle-dazzle than Finance. “The Judiciary Committee is a contentious and difficult committee to lead, but it may have more sway than the Finance Committee in the next divided Congress given the lack of ideological overlap between the incoming House Democratic majority and the Senate GOP majority on tax policy,” Burgess wrote. “Senate Republicans can confirm judicial nominees with no support from Democrats, which could make that job more influential in the coming months.”

RETTIG NOT SO CRYPTIC: Newly minted IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig has a message for virtual currency aficionados who try to game the tax system: We’re watching. “Given the agency’s ‘John Doe’ summons on the virtual currency exchange Coinbase, on which cryptocurrencies trade, the IRS has more information than many may imagine,” Rettig said in his first public comments since becoming commissioner last month, Aaron reports. “You think the IRS doesn’t know? You heard of Coinbase? Watch where we’re headed,” he said at the AICPA National Tax Conference. His comments seemed at least partly motivated by a demand from some House Ways and Means Republicans, including Brady, that the agency release updated guidance on how tax law applies to cryptocurrencies. The AICPA has made a similar request.

Rettig also promised a new level of cooperation between the IRS and tax practitioners, “saying they’re all in the business of tax compliance,” Aaron wrote. Toward that end of his speech, he said the agency would publicize internal training material on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act to give practitioners a better understanding of how it is implementing the law. “You’ll pick something up,” he told attendees at the AICPA gathering.

NEOMI, WE HARDLY NEW YE: The top regulator in the Trump administration, Neomi Rao, is the president’s pick to succeed Brett Kavanaugh on the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Rao’s Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs recently won the power to review Treasury Department tax regulations under an agreement between Treasury and OMB, the parent agency of OIRA.

Rao may actually have more influence on regulations if she’s confirmed by the Senate. Regulatory challenges often end up on the D.C. court’s docket and, as our Alex Guillen reported, “Rao has run Trump’s deregulatory agenda across the federal government.” She’s also a critic of the Chevron doctrine, which generally holds that agencies will get the benefit of the doubt in court cases involving ambiguous laws. The doctrine has played a role in numerous tax cases since the Supreme Court ruled in 2011 that it applies to Treasury regulations. In congressional testimony in 2016, when she was a law professor at George Mason University, Rao said Chevron “has allowed for the expansion of the administrative state outside the checks and balances of the Constitution,” Alex wrote.

INTERNATIONAL UPDATE

DAILY DIGITAL TAX UPDATE: The European Council “will consider tweaks to the EU’s digital tax proposal to shield financial services firms from the controversial levy on revenues, EU officials who are directly involved in the digital tax talks told POLITICO,” our colleague Bjarke Smith-Meyer reported. "Financial lobby groups, including the Association for Financial Markets in Europe and the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, have lobbied EU finance ministries in recent weeks about the need to mitigate unintended consequences of the proposed digital tax, such as capturing financial market activities provided through a ‘multisided digital interface.’”

Meanwhile, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said “Berlin was convinced a tax on the turnover of digital giants was necessary and wanted to figure out exactly how it should be imposed,” POLITICO Europe’s Laura Kayali reported. “’Germany is not asking whether [a digital tax is necessary], but how we are going to do this,’ she told the European Parliament in Strasbourg ... .” Germany had been notably cool recently to the idea of a digital tax.

STATE NEWS

TAKE A DEEP BREATH: Illinois may the next state to legalize recreational marijuana. House Speaker Michael Madigan says he supports Gov.-elect J.B. Pritzker's legalization plan, which Pritzker believes could generate up to $1 billion a year in tax revenue for the cash-strapped state, according to the Associated Press. Madigan, without whose blessing little happens in Illinois, also looks forward to working with fellow Democrat Pritzker on plans for a graduated income tax. As for outgoing Republican Gov. Bruce Rauner, Madigan had little to say: "I'm just happy that he's leaving."

QUICK LINKS

Moody's: Companies paying down debt with tax cut windfall.

Taxpayer Advocate wants five-year funding commitment from Congress for IT upgrades at IRS.

Forbes takes a look at the meals and entertainment deduction post-TCJA.

DID YOU KNOW?

Crystal City got its moniker from developer Robert H. Smith, who had a penchant for affixing the word "Crystal" to his properties — starting with Crystal House and followed by "Crystal Gateway, Crystal Towers, Crystal Square, Crystal Plaza, many of which were located on Crystal Drive, where Smith lived in a penthouse apartment," the Washington Post says.

content: With help from Brianna Gurciullo and Stephanie Beasley Editors Note: This edition of Morning Transportation is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Transportation subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn … [+10699 chars]
fulltext:
Amazon HQ a blessing or curse for NOVA, NY?

With help from Brianna Gurciullo and Stephanie Beasley

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Transportation is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Transportation subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

AMAZON’S DOUBLE-EDGED SWORD: In Northern Virginia and New York, Amazon’s plans to build new headquarters facilities are being described as either a golden opportunity to improve transportation infrastructure or an added burden to already overloaded systems. In Virginia, state and city governments are pledging more than half a billion dollars in transportation investments, including improvements to metro stations, a new pedestrian bridge and upgrades to Route 1, according to The Washington Post. But the arrival of tens of thousands of high-income workers to Crystal City (or should I say National Landing?) could displace residents, sending them to car-dependent suburbs and worsening gridlock. “If 25,000 jobs means 25,000 more cars, transportation is not going to work,” a D.C. council member told the Post.

LIC catastrophe? A few miles up I-95, some worry that the influx of workers for the planned Long Island City headquarters could add more strain to the city’s subway system, which already suffers from regular delays and overcrowding. “Amazon is a billion-dollar company. The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at a time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need MORE investment, not less, is extremely concerning to residents here,” wrote Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) on Twitter.

Potential impacts for TSA: Federal transportation leaders are keeping their eyes on Amazon’s move, too. Our Stephanie Beasley writes that TSA chief David Pekoske told reporters Tuesday that the agency is studying four airports in New York and Virginia near the company’s future headquarters to ensure they have sufficient staffing. "What we do is, is we look at projected passenger throughput levels well in advance — very carefully coordinated with the airlines and the airports — and then make our staffing adjustments well in advance of when we expect to see additional passengers arrive through the airports," he said.

IT’S WEDNESDAY: Thanks for tuning in to POLITICO’s Morning Transportation, your daily tipsheet on all things trains, planes, automobiles and ports. Get in touch with feedback, tips or song lyric suggestions at smintz@politico.com or @samjmintz.

Recently named a federal driverless car proving ground, Michigan’s American Center for Mobility offers real world testing environments to validate self-driving systems. Learn how public-private ventures are helping Michigan create a safer world. Visit PlanetM.com **

DENHAM DONE: Jeff Denham (R-Calif.), who chairs the Transportation railroads subcommittee, has been defeated by Democratic challenger Josh Harder, following an updated vote count on Tuesday. His loss all but assures that Missouri Republican Rep. Sam Graves, who currently leads the Highways and Transit Subcommittee, will be the ranking member on the full committee come January. Meanwhile, results are still out in Florida, where Commerce ranking member Bill Nelson remains locked in a recount battle with Republican Gov. Rick Scott. “This process is about one thing: Making sure every ballot is counted,” Nelson said at a press conference with Minority Leader Chuck Schumer on Tuesday. A hand recount could be triggered Thursday at the end of a machine recount, POLITICO Florida’s Marc Caputo reports. President Donald Trump ramped up the pressure on Nelson, calling on him to concede amid unproven allegations of “election theft.”

ON DECK TODAY: The Senate is expected to vote on passage of a Coast Guard reauthorization bill, S. 140 (115). Senators voted 93-5 to begin debate on the measure Tuesday evening. The bill would authorize funding for the service through fiscal 2019 and allow it to enter into multiyear contracting agreements for new National Security Cutters, among other items.

Infrastructure

HUNGRY FOR INFRASTRUCTURE: Sen. Roger Wicker (R-Miss.), who is expected to chair the Commerce Committee next year, told reporters Tuesday that he “would love to sink my teeth into an infrastructure package.” In terms of financing, Wicker is “interested in listening to suggestions, including those outside the box,” he said. “The 3P idea, any number of innovative solutions that states have been successful in doing would be food for thought.” Wicker added that soon-to-be House Transportation Chairman Peter DeFazio (D-Ore.) “said it had to be a realistic pay-for. And who could disagree with that?” He then asked: “What if we made the wall a part of the infrastructure package?” But he added: “I’m just asking questions.”

Nope: DeFazio quickly shot down the wall idea. “I have no interest in wading into that issue. Infrastructure should stand alone. It doesn’t need to be traded for anything,” he told MT. DeFazio said he wants to work with Trump on the issue, and come up with “real funding.” “But I’m not getting into the border wall, that’s not going to be a tradeoff, that’s not for me to do,” he said.

Ways and Means progress: DeFazio also told MT he spoke to House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi Tuesday night about the idea of creating a Ways and Means subcommittee specifically for infrastructure, which he has pushed for along with Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.). “I think we’re on track,” DeFazio said.

AUTOMOBILES

HITTING THE ROAD: The future is just about here. Self-driving car company Waymo is planning to launch the world’s first commercial driverless car service in the suburbs around Phoenix, Ariz., next month, according to Bloomberg. “The age-old guessing game of how long it will take for cars to drive themselves has come to an end. The better question now: How long will it take them to reach me?” writes Tom Randall. Another key question: Will Congress be able to catch up? Our Tanya Snyder wrote earlier this week that there’s pressure on the Senate to agree on a federal legislative framework for self-driving cars before the next Congress, and Waymo’s progress will add another reason to get a bill done.

Speaking of which: Commerce Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) said Tuesday that the fate of that bill, S. 1885 (115), will “depend entirely on the Democrats, coming out of the election, whether or not they want to get a deal.” There are “a couple of discrete issues where we haven’t been able to close the deal out,” Thune said. “But I think that if we can get consent to move something, I think it’s still possible to get it done. It would be really good if we did — the technology’s moving fast.” In response to a reporter’s question, Thune said the legislation could ride on a spending measure — “if we can get an agreement.”

Aviation

BOEING PROBE RAMPS UP: The FAA launched an investigation of Boeing’s safety analyses Tuesday, as part of the agency’s response to the deadly Lion Air crash in October. Investigators suspect that problems with a new automated flight-control system, which is part of the the company’s new 737 MAX models, may have played a role in the crash. The Wall Street Journal reports that FAA is reviewing details of the safety data and conclusions that Boeing had previously provided to the agency, as well as looking into training requirements for pilots.

Hill reaction: DeFazio told MT that he hasn’t been briefed by his staff yet, but is watching the story, which he said is a “very, very serious concern. Whenever you have the potential for a design flaw failure, that’s something we’ve got to get on right away.”

TURKEY DAY TRAVEL UPDATE: Stephanie reported Tuesday that TSA is gearing up for a potentially record-breaking level of Thanksgiving holiday travel by adding new screening technology and implementing a contentious canine screening program. The agency is using automated screening lanes, 3D computed tomography scanners and ID authentication tech, and adding 1,200 agents and 80 canine teams. Pekoske said the agency will also continue to use expedited canine screening, which has been criticized by lawmakers, at least through the end of the year. Airlines for America is projecting that 30.6 million passengers will fly on U.S. airlines from Nov. 16-27.

Rail

I THINK I CAN: Two Democratic members of the House Transportation railroads subpanel told MT on Tuesday that they sure wouldn’t mind chairing the panel in the next Congress. “If the opportunity presented itself, I would jump at the opportunity,” Rep. Donald Payne of New Jersey said. “But there are a lot of members that are senior to me in the actual Dem caucus. So we’re still trying to figure that whole thing out.” On the Transportation Committee, Reps. Grace Napolitano (D-Calif.), Albio Sires (D-N.J.), John Garamendi (D-Calif.) and André Carson (D-Ind.) are among those more senior than Payne, he noted. “I haven’t actually said I’m interested,” Payne added. “I’m finding out if they’re interested,” he said about his colleagues.

Meanwhile: Illinois Rep. Dan Lipinski, who is more senior than Payne, said he is “definitely” interested in leading the rail subcommittee. But he added: “It depends on what everyone else’s interests are, too.”

THE AUTOBAHN

content: With help from Megan Cassella, Nancy Cook, Ben White and Sabrina Rodriguez Editors Note: This edition of Morning Trade is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Trade subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To lear… [+10561 chars]

The winding road to the G-20

With help from Megan Cassella, Nancy Cook, Ben White and Sabrina Rodriguez

Editor’s Note: This edition of Morning Trade is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Trade subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro’s comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

WHAT TO EXPECT: President Donald Trump and senior officials have been discussing how to approach China as a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping approaches. European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström meets with U.S. Trade Representative Robert LIghthizer today and hopes Trump keeps his promise of keeping auto tariffs at bay. The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission wants the U.S. to step up its fight against China at the WTO. Start here:

THE WINDING ROAD TO THE G-20: Trump’s strategy ahead of a high-stakes meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping is about as clear as mud, but there has been some work behind the scenes. Trump met last Thursday with his envoy to Beijing, Terry Branstad, as well as Lighthizer, Secretary of State Michael Pompeo and chief of staff John Kelly. The meeting was supposed to map out the best way to talk to China about national security and trade, said a source briefed on the meeting.

The White House wants to “push the Chinese to where they need to get in order to make a deal,” the source said about the upcoming meeting, and thinks China is ready to do that now that Republicans showed they could maintain control of the Senate.

The Mnuchin angle: It’s still unclear what Trump wants to get out of Xi during the face-to-face, but China watchers say they are wary of news that Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin could meet in the coming weeks with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He ahead of the G-20 meeting. As of Friday, USTR had not been involved in the planning of that meeting, said one source familiar with the planning. Even at Treasury, staff-level China experts haven’t been involved in planning for a potential meeting or preparation for the G-20 get together, according to two sources close to the process.

“If USTR is not involved, then we have the same problem as before,” said one of the sources, referring to a failed effort to reach a deal in May that was led by Mnuchin. Hardliners fear that another effort with Mnuchin at the helm could lead to an outcome that doesn’t pressure Beijing to address substantive issues related to China’s intellectual property and technology transfer policies.

IT'S WEDNESDAY, NOV. 14! Welcome to Morning Trade, where your host is hoping to catch the meteor shower this weekend. Got any trade wishes you want to see come true? Let me know: abehsudi@politico.com or @abehsudi.

COFFEE AND CONVERSATION — The Pro Canada team and POLITICO Senior Politics Editor Charlie Mahtesian are joining the Nelson Mullins law firm for a breakfast briefing Thursday on the implications of the midterm elections for U.S.-Canada relations. Kicking things off will be Nelson Mullins partner and former U.S. Ambassador to Canada David Wilkins. Get the details and sign up.

KUDLOW UNLEASHES ON NAVARRO’S CHINA COMMENTS: As if we weren’t confused enough about what message the administration is trying to send to China ahead of the meeting between Trump and Xi, National Economic Council Director Larry Kudlow said White House trade adviser Peter Navarro did the president a “great disservice” in his remarks last Friday.

“He was not speaking for the president, nor was he speaking for the administration. His remarks were way off base. They were not authorized by anybody,” Kudlow said on CNBC on Tuesday.

Navarro had said there would be a “stench” around any deal that involves the influence of Goldman Sachs and other Wall Street players. Kudlow said the president “can talk to whomever he can talk to. He talks to people on Wall Street, yes.”

Kudlow added that “we’re having communications at all levels of U.S. and Chinese government.”

Koch groups weigh in on G-20: The Koch network of free trade groups are urging Trump and Xi to end the trade war between the world’s two largest economies. In a letter released this morning, Americans for Prosperity, Freedom Partners and The Libre Initiative called for dropping the tariffs, which they say have hurt the global economy.

NO CAR TARIFFS YET; MALMSTRÖM STILL EXPECTS EU REPRIEVE: The Commerce Department is still working on its report on whether imports of autos and auto part imports threaten national security, according to a senior administration official — but when it recommends tariffs as expected, European Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström wants the U.S. to keep its promise to spare the EU.

“We assume if that were to happen, that would not be for the European Union,” Malmström said Tuesday in remarks at the German Marshall Fund.

Commerce’s Section 232 investigation could allow Trump to impose 20 percent or 25 percent duties on auto and auto part imports.

Malmström is halfway through a two-day trip to the United States to discuss the parameters of future negotiations. Malmström will meet with Lighthizer today. Doug has more here.

CHINA COMMISSION URGES NEW FIGHT AT WTO: The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission is encouraging Congress to step up the fight against China’s trade practices in its annual report to Congress today.

Top among 26 recommendations is that lawmakers urge the administration to pursue a rarely invoked “non-violation nullification or impairment" case against Beijing at the WTO. That type of case would allow countries to challenge China for economic practices that don’t violate specific WTO rules but prevent Beijing from meeting its obligation to maintain a open and market-oriented economy.

“It’s quite clear [President Xi Jinping] and the Chinese communist party have taken control of the economy and not necessarily in the most healthy or productive way,” commission Chairwoman Robin Cleveland told reporters Tuesday. Read the full story here.

HOW THE CHINA TRADE FIGHT COULD GET EVEN WORSE: Consumers have not yet felt a major hit from Trump’s trade battle with China, but that could change later this year if the countries cannot make a deal. In the latest POLITICO Money podcast, our Doug Palmer explains the potential for Trump to hit more than $500 billion in Chinese imports with tariffs as high as 25 percent over the coming months.

U.S. COUNTER-NOTIFIES AT THE WTO: The U.S. called out India at the WTO for underreporting the extent of its market price support for cotton. The move, known as a “counter notification,” is part of a broader effort by the U.S. to pressure WTO members to fully disclose subsidies and other domestic measures that affect trade. The U.S. calculated that India’s cotton support program exceeded its allowable threshold for trade-distorting domestic support.

FRUSTRATION MOUNTS OVER TARIFF EXCLUSION ‘MESS’: The Commerce Department’s tariff exclusion process was meant to ease the burden on U.S. companies that rely on imports, but the Aluminum Association is arguing that even after proposed reforms, the complicated operation is only making things worse.

"The inherent uncertainty of the product exclusion process is actually adding an unnecessarily prolonged cost burden to our members and their customers and chilling investment in the aluminum industry, rather than promoting domestic production," the group said in a letter sent Tuesday to Commerce Department officials.

Lauren Wilk, vice president for policy at the Aluminum Association, added in an interview: “It’s kind of a mess.” Doug has more for Pros here.

TRADE STAFF SWITCH-UP AT FINANCE: Nasim Fussell will take over as chief international trade counsel for Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee. She was previously deputy chief trade counsel on the committee. Shane Warren, who fills the top trade staffer position, will be leaving after five years on the panel, a Finance spokeswoman told Morning Trade.

Fussell joined the committee earlier this year after working as director of government and regulatory affairs at Pitney Bowes, a mailing equipment and services company. She also served as a trade counsel on the House Ways and Means Committee, working under the chairmanships of Dave Camp (R-Mich.), Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Kevin Brady (R-Texas). During her time on the House panel, she worked to advance trade promotion authority, customs, trade preferences and miscellaneous tariff bill legislation.

Chairman question mark: Sen. Chuck Grassley is still on the short list of lawmakers who could take the Finance chairmanship when Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-Utah) leaves Congress after this term. But the Iowa Republican said he needs more time to discuss the possible move with his colleagues. To take the top spot on Finance, Grassley would have to give up the gavel to the Judiciary Committee.

“You ask me that in a few days and I’ll have an answer for you,” Grassley told reporters on Tuesday. POLITICO’s Burgess Everett has more here on the committee scene in next year’s Senate.

AFTER TARIFFS, SPANISH OLIVE IMPORTS DROP 72 PERCENT: Imports of Spanish table olives to the U.S. dropped by nearly three-quarters in August and September, the first two months after anti-subsidy and anti-dumping duties went into effect, the Spanish olive farmers association ASAMESA said Tuesday.

Following a complaint from Californian olive producers, which claimed their Spanish competitors benefited from unfair subsidies, Washington in July imposed hefty tariffs ranging from 30 percent to 45 percent on Spanish table olives. Madrid and the European Commission strongly reject the justification for those duties.

Brussels still in talks: The European Commission said Tuesday it continues to raise the issue with U.S. authorities — including during Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross’ visit to Brussels last month — but has not yet decided whether it would launch a WTO case.

INTERNATIONAL OVERNIGHT

— Vice President Mike Pence says Trump is leaving the door open to making a deal with Xi at the G-20, if the Chinese president agrees to massive economic, political and military changes, a Washington Post columnist writes.

— Vietnam becomes the seventh country to ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership, Reuters reports.

— Deputy White House national security adviser Mira Ricardel will soon be dismissed from her job, CNN reports.

— The United Kingdom and EU have agreed on the draft text of a Brexit agreement, the BBC reports.

THAT'S ALL FOR MORNING TRADE! See you again soon! In the meantime, drop the team a line: abehsudi@politico.com and @abehsudi; mcassella@politico.com and @mmcassella; dpalmer@politico.com and @tradereporter; srodriguez@politico.com and @sabrod123; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny. Also follow us @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Trade.

content: With help from Arthur Allen ( @arthurallen202 ) and Mohana Ravindranath ( @ravindranize ) Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning eHealth is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro eHealth subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each … [+9383 chars]

What’s happening today

With help from Arthur Allen (@arthurallen202) and Mohana Ravindranath (@ravindranize)

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning eHealth is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro eHealth subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

WHAT’S HAPPENING TODAY: Today will be another busy day in Washington — headlined by a hearing on the VA’s EHR implementation progress:

— VA hearing may probe lack of light from “Lighthouse”: The House Veterans Affairs’ tech modernization subcommittee will grill the chief of the Cerner EHR implementation, John Windom, at a hearing today. The program’s acting chief medical officer, Laura Kroupa, technology officer John Short and Travis Dalton from Cerner are also on the menu.

In a letter last month, subcommittee chair Jim Banks jabbed at the VA’s apparent failure to move forward its Lighthouse EHR modernization project, which was underway before the Cerner decision and includes the creation of an open API gateway.

If you’ll recall, leading health systems signed an API pledge with the VA at HIMSS in March, but some of those companies are reportedly grumbling that the VA’s work on the project appears dormant. The pledge calls for speeding the mapping of health data to industry standards using FHIR.

We asked former White House Chief Technology Officer Aneesh Chopra, a big proponent of the open API push, about these concerns, but Chopra wasn’t worried about the delay, given leadership changes at the VA. “The whole idea of an API gateway is new to health care,” he said.

The VA’s tech chops have been under close scrutiny of late: earlier this week, NBC News reported that veterans nationwide are suffering from software glitches delaying payment of their benefits.

(For what it’s worth, department secretary Robert Wilkie declared the VA crisis “over” last Friday.)

— HITAC meeting postponed: Meanwhile, the Health IT Advisory Committee meeting originally scheduled for today has been postponed. Office spokesman Peter Ashkenaz tells Morning eHealth that the committee’s next hearing will be in December, though without a settled date.

The reason for the postponement? Ashkenaz says that the interoperability standards priorities task force isn’t ready to present its final recommendations.

Meanwhile, committee member Steven Lane tells us the office is gearing up for a rule drop — presumably the interoperability or info blocking rules currently parked in the Office of Management and Budget’s review process — which might be part of the agenda for a HITAC meeting. Says Ashkenaz, asked about any rules-drop-preparations: “We are?”

eHealth tweets of the day: Chris Hogg @cwhogg “… [on the clinical trials app Driver going out of business] No product/market, no business, 85(!) employees left hanging, paying customers left without service or refunds. yikes.”

David Shaywitz @DShaywitz “[quoting] Next time folks wonder why pharma and clinical organizations are often so reluctant to rely on startups for stuff beyond consequence-free pilots...”

WEDNESDAY: Hoping readers can resolve a question for your correspondent. Your correspondent rented a car over the weekend. He’s not ordinarily a driver, and therefore isn’t covered by insurance. Other than the insurance one gets on a credit card, does he need to get additional coverage at the rental place? Answer this one at dtahir@politico.com. Or make fun of upsales on social media at @arthurallen202, @dariustahir, @ravindranize, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_eHealth.

UPDATES FROM AMA INTERIM MEETING: Over at National Harbor, the AMA has been promulgating several new policies at its interim meeting. A lot of them touch on eHealth. The Association is calling on the government and payors to collect demographic data reflecting a variety of sexual and gender identities; it’s hoping to encourage physicians to educate themselves in population and public health for patients without good access to care; and it’s calling for expansion of broadband and wireless to undeserved areas to promote digital health.

HEALTH IT BUSINESS WATCH

We’ve got a heaping helping of business news to serve up:

— Q&A with Munjal Shah: Getting health-conscious people better deals on life insurance is the business model for startup Health IQ. In a conversation with our colleague Arthur Allen, CEO Munjal Shah says that a 30-question quiz can help sort out health-knowledgeable from health-naïve consumers, and get the former group some nice quotes on life insurance.

“People do a lot for savings. People do a lot of things to save money,” he said. Pros can get the rest here.

— Alphabet re-orgs health work: Alphabet is reshuffling the org chart for its health care companies, CNBC’s Christina Farr reports. The company is moving the health parts of its DeepMind subsidiary into its Google Health unit. (Here’s more detail in the firm’s blog.) Notably, the firm is pledging that data gathered as part of its partnership with Britain’s NHS won’t be used “for commercial purposes like advertising or insurance.” (An early partnership had led to an uproar from British lawmakers and the public. They feared the potential damages to privacy.)

— Oscar sues Florida Blue: Buzzy insurance startup Oscar Health is entering a court battle. The company filed a lawsuit against Florida Blue Cross and Blue Shield Tuesday. The suit alleges that 190 brokers backed out of agreements to sell Oscar’s insurance plans, prompted by Florida Blue’s threats.

"Florida Blue's monopoly power in Florida makes its scheme devastating to a new entrant like Oscar, as well as deeply injurious to Florida consumers," according to the complaint filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida.

Florida Blue said it's reviewing the complaint but "from what we know of the New York company's grievances, there is no merit to them at all." Contracted agents are independent and can choose whether to work with carriers that operate on an exclusive basis, Florida Blue says. You can read the complaint here, and our colleague Paul Demko’s write-up of the legal tactics here.

— Virta Health makes big bet on new biz model: Virta Health — a company that hopes to reverse type 2 diabetes through diet change — is announcing a new payment model: 100% of its fees are at risk, the startup is announcing today.

“Now that we have both clinical trial and commercial results demonstrating diabetes reversal and cost savings at scale, we are ready to align our economic incentives with those of patients and payers by putting 100 percent of our fees at risk,” said the startup’s co-founder, Sami Inkinen. “I am hopeful that the rest of the healthcare industry will follow and transition away from fee-for-service based health care.”

The company estimates it can save payors nearly $10,000 per patient over the first two years.

— Facebook answers on privacy: In answers to the Senate Intelligence Committee for a hearing on operatives’ use of social media to influence debate in America, Facebook admitted that users do not have the ability to opt out of research conducted on them.

“In our Data Policy, we explain that we may use the information we have to conduct and support research in areas that may include general social welfare, technological advancement, public interest, health, and well-being,” the letter says. “Researchers are subject to strict restrictions regarding data access and use as part of these collaborations.”

The hearing comes amid a climate of hot controversy over tech firms’ privacy practices. Legislators from both sides of the aisle have at least publicly said they’re interested in a national privacy bill that might affect health care.

IN THE COURTS

TRUMP TO NOMINATE OIRA CHIEF TO FEDERAL JUDGESHIP: President Trump is nominating Neomi Rao, the head of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, to Brett Kavanaugh’s old seat on the DC Circuit, he announced Tuesday. As head of OIRA, Rao oversees the flow of regulatory and deregulatory actions — playing a role in virtually all of the administration’s regulatory actions. Rao, if confirmed, will move to one of the most powerful courts in the country — a finishing school for the Supreme Court.

WHAT WE'RE CLICKING

Vox deconstructs the period-tracking app space

Chilmark Research discusses how CMS’s telehealth moves with affect the market

The Journal of Medical Internet Research analyses the EHR as educational tool

With help from Ian Kullgren, Helena Bottemiller Evich, Ted Hesson, and Timothy Noah

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Shift is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Employment & Immigration subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

SCARED OFF FOOD STAMPS?: As the Trump administration readies a final regulation that would make it harder for immigrants who’ve received food stamps or other government benefits to secure a green card, a new study by Boston Medical Center’s Children’s HealthWatch reports that participation by eligible immigrant families in the food-stamp program fell nearly 10 percentage points during the first half of 2018.

This finding, which came from surveying more than 35,000 mothers of children four years and younger in Boston, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Minneapolis, and Little Rock, reverses a ten-year trend. Participation in the food stamp program by eligible immigrant families rose to 43 percent in 2007-2017 before declining in 2018 to 34.8 percent. Heated immigration rhetoric and increased enforcement and detention are “a likely reason for many people dropping out,” Allison Bovell-Ammon, lead researcher on the study, told Evich (though she conceded that “it could also be because the economy is improving.”) Ellen Vollinger, legal/SNAP director at the Food Research & Action Center, a D.C. nonprofit, said: “I think this data really does confirm these anecdotes we've been hearing.” More from POLITICO’s Helena Bottemiller Evich here.

GOOD MORNING! It’s Nov. 14, and this is Morning Shift, POLITICO's daily tipsheet on employment and immigration policy. Send tips, exclusives, and suggestions to rrainey@politico.com, thesson@politico.com, ikullgren@politico.com and tnoah@politico.com. Follow us on Twitter at @RebeccaARainey, @tedhesson, @IanKullgren and @TimothyNoah1.

Join Nelson Mullins and POLITICO for a breakfast briefing on the implications of the midterm elections for U.S.-Canada relations. Introductory remarks by Nelson Mullins partner David Wilkins, a former U.S. ambassador to Canada, will be followed by a POLITICO reporter briefing. RSVP here.

HR FOR JUDGES: The federal judiciary on Tuesday acquired its first-ever director of workplace relations. Chief Judge Sidney R. Thomas of the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco announced Tuesday that the appeals court had hired Yohance Claude Edwards, who previously was associate director and deputy Title IX officer in Berkeley’s Office for the Prevention of Harassment and Discrimination. As director of workplace relations for the Ninth Circuit, Edwards will supervise development of a training program to prevent discrimination and harassment. More here.

US OPPOSES REFUGEE COMPACT: The United States was the only country Tuesday to vote against a U.N. General Assembly resolution on refugees, Reuters’ Michelle Nichols reports. U.S. officials opposed the annual measure “because it said elements of the text ran counter to the Trump administration’s sovereign interests,” according to Reuters. More here.

UNIONS

USW RATIFIES U.S. STEEL CONTRACT: The United Steelworkers union yesterday voted to ratify a new contract with U.S. Steel, concluding a battle over the sharing of windfall profits from President Donald Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs. The contract includes a 14 percent pay increase over four years and increases retirement benefits for 16,000 workers, according to the union.

“In 2015, workers recognized that the steel industry was struggling and agreed to make sacrifices so that U.S. Steel could get through some tough times,” United Steelworkers President Leo Gerard said in a statement. "Now that the company has recovered and is projected to earn nearly $2 billion this year, workers rightly wanted a share of that success."

The raise doesn’t come close to absorbing the bulk of new profits reported by U.S. Steel. This month, the company reported third-quarter earnings double those in 2017 — $291 million compared to $147 million, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported.

USW this month reached a tentative agreement with ArcelorMittal, which together with U.S. Steel accounts for 40 percent of the country's flat-rolled steel production. Members have yet to ratify that contract.

JOBS, JOBS, JOBS

WASHINGTON V. CRYSTAL CITY?: Amazon on Tuesday confirmed that Crystal City, Virginia, and Long Island City, N.Y., won the yearlong bidding competition for the company's new headquarters, POLITICO’s Steven Overly reports. But will Crystal City’s proximity to the Capitol cut into the pool of tech workers that the federal government needs?

“If Amazon presents itself as competitive, they will steal away a lot of young federal employees. That’s the first group that will be affected,” Steve Lenkart, executive director of the National Federation of Federal Employees, told Bloomberg Law. “The second group is applicants. The federal government will have a tough time competing” with a private-sector employer that can offer higher pay (expected to average more than $150,000) and better benefits for people with needed skills, Louis C. LeBrecque writes. More here.

Labor unions, meanwhile, worry that the move could exacerbate housing and income gaps in the capital region. “It is critical that HQ2 and its sustaining infrastructure be built and run by workers who receive fair wages, strong benefits, and the dignity on the job that comes with union representation,” said a Tuesday statement signed by Local 25, LiUNA Baltimore/Washington Council, CHOICE, and UFCW Local 400. “Otherwise, HQ2 will turn our housing and inequality crises into full-blown catastrophes.” Read the statement here.

HOMAN AT HOMELAND?: “President Donald Trump is considering Thomas Homan, former acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, to succeed Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen,” POLITICO’s Gabby Orr and Ted Hesson report. The Washington Post reported late Monday that Trump could announce Nielsen’s ouster as soon as this week.

“The tough-talking lawman once recommended charging so-called sanctuary city politicians ‘with crimes’ and has pugnaciously defended even Trump’s most controversial immigration moves, including separating children from their parents at the border.” More here.

POLITICO Live is hosting an editorial panel, “Using tech to tackle the high unemployment rate of military spouses” as part of the USO’s Salute to Military Spouses summit. The panel will be moderated by Jacqueline Klimas, National Security Reporter, POLITICO, and begins at 11:40 a.m. Watch a livestream here.

Parkland panel convenes marathon meeting

With help from Kimberly Hefling

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Education is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Education subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

PARKLAND PANEL CONVENES MARATHON MEETING: A Florida panel charged with investigating the Valentine’s Day shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School is expected to hear from the Broward County sheriff’s deputy who resigned amid widespread criticism for failing to confront the school shooter.

— Commissioners are eager to question former Deputy Scot Peterson, who was subpoenaed to testify and is scheduled to appear on Thursday afternoon. But there’s no guarantee he’ll even show for the much-anticipated testimony — the agenda includes a warning he may be unwilling to participate. Details of the agenda here. Watch the meetings live.

— Tuesday’s testimony revealed numerous missed warning signs about the Parkland shooter, including that he threatened on multiple occasions to commit a school shooting, made specific threats against black and Jewish people and brought knives, bullets and decapitated animals to school. Most of these incidents, which involved classmates, went unreported until law enforcement began investigating the Feb. 14 massacre. Commissioners implored people to report potential threats instead of brushing them off. More from POLITICO Florida’s Andrew Atterbury.

— The panel is holding a marathon meeting this week. The four-day session comes after Hurricane Michael canceled the commission’s October meeting. The Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School Public Safety Commission, created by a bill signed by Republican Gov. Rick Scott in March, has only one more scheduled gathering before its recommendations for improving school safety and security are due to state lawmakers on Jan.1. Andrew has more.

— The commissioners — who include parents who lost children in the shooting — will hear other difficult testimony this week, including about security measures at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, the shooter’s internet searches and cell phone content, 911 calls, radio transmissions as the tragedy unfolded, and the FBI’s review of the shooting. Broward County officials, including Superintendent Robert Runcie and Sheriff Scott Israel are also expected to testify on Thursday.

GOOD WEDNESDAY MORNING, NOV. 14. I guess my neighborhood is technically part of “National Landing” now, according to Amazon. While this is how I initially felt about the Northern Virginia rebranding, I look forward to the infrastructure improvements that are (reportedly) on the way! Talk to me: cemma@politico.com or @caitlinzemma. Send events to: educalendar@politicopro.com. And follow us on Twitter: @Morning_Edu and @POLITICOPro.

School Safety

AND THEN THERE WERE TWO? Half of the Cabinet officials comprising the White House school safety commission may soon be gone. President Donald Trump fired Attorney General Jeff Sessions last week and is reportedly looking to remove Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen.

— Education Secretary Betsy DeVos chairs the Federal School Safety Commission — which the White House launched earlier this year in response to the Parkland shooting. HHS Secretary Alex Azar is also a member. Senior agency officials have participated in the commission’s meetings when Cabinet officials have been unavailable. The panel is expected to produce a report detailing its recommendations by year’s end.

— Advocates expect that report to address controversial issues like arming teachers and school discipline, in addition to student data sharing and privacy, school building security, and mental health. Conservatives are hoping the commission scraps Obama-era guidelines on school discipline, which they see as a burden on school districts and possibly dangerous because of their potential to keep violent children in school. The guidelines were issued in 2014 with the goal of ensuring that schools aren’t discriminating against students while disciplining them.

— In other school safety news: Frank Brogan, who leads the Education Department’s Office of Elementary and Secondary Education, will update state education leaders about the commission’s progress. Brogan will speak today at an annual policy forum hosted by the Council of Chief State School Officers, an organization that represents state education chiefs nationwide. The forum is in Long Beach, Calif., and Brogan is expected to speak at 11 a.m. local time.

ELECTION WATCH

OJEDA FOR PRESIDENT: West Virginia state legislator Richard Ojeda — a passionate supporter of striking state teachers earlier this year — has announced he’s running for president only days after losing his bid for West Virginia’s 3rd District. Ojeda, a Democrat, lost last week to Republican Carol Miller. His first campaign ad shows him against the backdrop of teachers who marched on the state capitol last spring for better pay and more school funding. Watch it here.

HIGHER EDUCATION

PRESSURE BUILDS ON VA TO ADDRESS GI BILL PROCESSING DELAYS: Veterans Affairs officials are slated to appear Thursday before a House Veterans’ Affairs Committee panel demanding to know what the VA is doing to address GI Bill processing delays. Bipartisan pressure has been building on the VA to fix the IT-related problems.

— “This is an unnecessary and preventable crisis, and the Department of Veterans Affairs must take immediate action to remedy it,” House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) said Tuesday in a statement.

— Paul R. Lawrence, the undersecretary for benefits in the VA’s Veterans Benefit Administration, is among the officials expected to speak at the hearing, which starts at 4 p.m. in 334 Cannon.

— Meanwhile, the group Veterans Education Success plans to release an issue brief today that explores why selective colleges enroll far fewer veterans pursuing undergraduate degrees than graduate-level programs. The brief will be released at a College Board conference in Arlington, Va., focused on improving college opportunities for veterans.

VIRGINIA TECH TO OPEN NORTHERN VIRGINIA CAMPUS NEAR AMAZON SITE: Virginia Tech says it will build a 1-million-square-foot campus in Alexandria, Va., that will complement Amazon's new headquarters site. The $1 billion project will focus on providing graduate degree programs and research opportunities in computer sciences and software engineering.

— Virginia Tech President Tim Sands told Morning Education the idea to build an innovation campus had been in the works for about four years. But when the possibility of Amazon building a second headquarters in the region came under discussion, school officials accelerated that effort.

— “When Amazon and the state came calling about 14 months ago, and asked us to help lead a higher education package that would provide the talent resources that a company like Amazon and any company would need, we stepped right up and said that’s what we’re working on right now,’” Sands said. “So, we’ll just dovetail this into our plans.”

— Meanwhile, Jennifer Wexton, the Democrat who last week defeated Republican Rep. Barbara Comstock to represent Virginia’s 10th District, raised concerns about whether Northern Virginia has “the necessary infrastructure, including roads, transit, schools and affordable housing, to properly welcome Amazon to our region.”

— Amazon is building a second HQ in Long Island City, New York. One Democratic state lawmaker wants to halt the flow of any taxpayer money to the retail giant. “Democratic Assemblyman Ron Kim announced that he will introduce legislation to slash New York’s economic development subsidies and use the money to buy up and cancel student debt — a move he said would provide a bigger boost to the state’s economy,” Capital & Main reports.

— Chalkbeat looks at how Amazon’s arrival could impact students in New York.

DEVOS SUED OVER LOAN DISCHARGES FOR STUDENTS AT CLOSED SCHOOLS: A California consumer advocacy group on Tuesday sued DeVos for failing to automatically cancel the federal loans owed by students whose education was interrupted by the sudden closure of their colleges. The lawsuit seeks a court order requiring DeVos to carry out the automatic loan discharges for students who attended hundreds of campuses that closed before the students could complete their academic programs. Michael Stratford has more.

TEXAS TO KEEP CLINTON IN HISTORY CURRICULUM: The Texas State Board of Education on Tuesday night reversed course and voted to keep Hillary Clinton, Helen Keller and other historical figures in the state’s social studies curriculum. The state board voted in September to cut Clinton in an effort to “streamline” the curriculum. But backlash was swift, with groups accusing state education officials of allowing politics to influence what kids are taught. The state board will take a final vote on the overall curriculum at week’s end. More from the Dallas Morning News.

REPORT ROLL CALL

— The Indianapolis-based school choice advocacy group EdChoice is out with a look at where newly elected governors stand on private school choice.

— The National Association of Charter School Authorizers released educational videos this week explaining what charter school authorizers do and why they’re important for quality charter schools. “Authorizers are the entities that decide who can start a new charter school, set academic and operational expectations, and oversee school performance,” NACSA explains.

— The left-leaning Center for American Progress is out with a new analysis of school finance litigation.

— A new home visiting yearbook by the National Home Visiting Resource Center finds that 18 million pregnant women and families aren’t being served by home visiting programs, despite meeting the criteria of those who could benefit.

— The Saul Zaentz Early Education Initiative at the Harvard Graduate School of Education finds that more than half of 3- and 4-year-olds studied in Massachusetts were enrolled in some kind of formal educational or care setting.

— The Annie E. Casey Foundation reports on the challenges that foster youth face as they transition into adulthood.

SYLLABUS

— Some California schools to remain closed through Thanksgiving due to wildfires: KTLA.

— In a shift, more education reformers say they’re worried about schools’ focus on testing: Chalkbeat.
