title: ‘Cybersecurity moonshot’ gets vote today
description: The Four Horsemen of cyber war — House, Senate panels look at DoD, DHS cyber setups
content: With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6… [+10894 chars]
fulltext:
‘Cybersecurity moonshot’ gets vote today

With help from Eric Geller, Martin Matishak and Christian Vasquez

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Cybersecurity is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Cybersecurity subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

THE CYBER EAGLE HAS LANDED — A federal advisory committee is meeting today to approve a report urging President Donald Trump to create a “cybersecurity moonshot” project, modeled somewhat on the Apollo program, with the goal of securing the internet by 2028. “Because we took a moonshot approach of going out 10 years, we were able to open up our view and look laterally, and not just look at new technologies or advances in technology or existing technology,” Peter Altabef, who co-chaired the group that prepared the report, told Eric. There has been no shortage of reports urging massive changes to the internet ecosystem, but Altabef said the cyber moonshot was “fundamentally different.”

One thing that distinguishes the moonshot, according to Altabef, is its focus on interdependencies in networked technology. “I don’t think that has been done before,” he said. “Most cybersecurity efforts are near-term, interim, and relatively piecemeal.” He also argued that the report’s tight recommended timeframe would spur action. “This is a 10-year effort, but it is also a six-month effort and a one-year effort,” he said. “So there’s urgency to this. It is not all ‘wake up in 10 years and it’s fixed.’ We expect significant things to be happening during this process.”

The moonshot report is the product of more than a year of effort by a subcommittee of the National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee, whose members have kept in close touch with officials at DHS and other agencies. “We are working in this effort with various parts of the administration very, very well,” Altabef said, describing officials as “very supportive.”

“We’re kind of at a watershed moment,” said Altabef, who argued that the U.S. had to yet experience a “Sputnik moment” in cybersecurity. “We can wait for that to occur,” he said, “or we can start something like this and try to head that off. … That becomes a whole-of-nation effort.”

HAPPY WEDNESDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity! Wait, what? Send your thoughts, feedback and especially tips to tstarks@politico.com, and be sure to follow @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info below.

THE FOUR HORSEMEN — In fall 2008, a U.S. service member stuck an infected USB flash drive into a laptop and set off a chain of events that would lead to the creation of U.S. Cyber Command. Now, as the president unshackles the organization, the architects of the newest U.S. military command offer rare insights into its origins and mission.

A decade ago, the U.S. military was just beginning to confront the risk of digital espionage and cyber warfare. “What [Defense Secretary Robert Gates] came up with and we discussed was, how do you better defend? Why do we have the offense and the defense in separate teams? Why don’t you put those together?” former NSA chief Keith Alexander told Martin. “If you’re going to set up a new command, you need to do all the planning for that. How do you get the right folks to do that?”

They became known as “the Four Horsemen,” a brain trust tasked with hammering out the plan to build the country’s first cyber warfare command and explaining it to a skeptical Washington. Today, Trump has formally elevated its status and made it the Defense Department’s newest “unified combatant command,” only the 10th of its kind. The promotion was followed a series of policy moves by the White House that, taken together, show a willingness to act first and ask questions later in the digital domain. “Our hands are not tied as they were in the Obama administration,” national security adviser John Bolton said in September. “We’re going to do a lot of things offensively, and our adversaries need to know that,” he added. Pros can read the full story here.

TODAY: FRIENDSHIP IS MAGIC — Two House panels combine their powers today for a hearing on cybersecurity cooperation between DHS and DoD. “It is imperative that the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Defense work hand in glove to protect our nation’s systems, and to provide assistance to our critical infrastructure partners,” Rep. John Ratcliffe, chairman of the House Homeland Security cybersecurity subcommittee, says in prepared opening remarks. Also imperative, according to Ratcliffe: that DHS take the lead. “A civilian led system embodies what the foundation that this democracy was built on.” Ratcliffe’s panel is teaming with the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities for the hearing.

Across the Capitol, the Senate Armed Services cyber subcommittee scrutinizes DoD cybersecurity acquisition practices. “While we have confidence that the Department will bolster its cybersecurity in due time, we believe that this improvement could come as a result of improved cooperation with private sector cybersecurity companies and reconfiguration of the Department’s cybersecurity capabilities to match the state-of-the-art offerings in the private sector,” Sen. Mike Rounds, chairman of the subcommittee, says in prepared remarks.

MAYBE SOME PEOPLE ARE LEAVING? — A possible Trump administration shakeup post-midterms had apparently claimed its first victim Tuesday only for The Wall Street Journal to walk back the story — although there could still be a reckoning ahead. The Journal reported that Mira Ricardel, Bolton’s top deputy, had been escorted out of the White House, but the administration denied that. Still, Melania Trump’s rare public appeal doesn’t bode well for Ricardel, who was an advocate of eliminating the White House cybersecurity coordinator position and absorbing its duties into her portfolio, as we reported back in May.

DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen’s head is also on the block, potentially, but there’s no permanent deputy secretary in place. Claire Grady is acting deputy and would assume the job if Nielsen is pushed out. While Grady has served as the DHS face on some cybersecurity discussions since assuming the role, it’s not a major part of her background. Former Immigration and Customs Enforcement chief Thomas Homan, whose background is in law enforcement, is in the mix for long-term replacements, any of whom might shift attention away from cyber. With wildfires raging in California, the timing might be problematic for the president, given DHS’s emergency management role.

CISA’S ON ITS WAY — The House on Tuesday evening sent a bill (H.R. 3359) to Trump reorganizing DHS’s main cyber division into the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection Agency. Nielsen, Ratcliffe and others applauded the House for clearing the legislation. The measure, which Trump is expected to sign given that every leading DHS official and even Vice President Mike Pence lobbied for it, will “bolster public-private partnerships to help ensure businesses have the resources and support necessary before, during, and after a cyber incident,” said Christopher Roberti, the senior vice president for cyber, intelligence and security policy at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

OPM STILL WEAK ON CYBER — The Office of Personnel Management still has a ways to go to secure its data, according to a Government Accountability Office report released Tuesday. Nearly a third of the 80 recommendations by the GAO after the 2015 breach have not been implemented, leaving the agency that maintains personal data on millions of current and former federal workers “at increased risk of unauthorized access, use, disclosure, modification, or disruption,” the report concluded. However, OPM plans to implement most of the remaining recommendations by the end of fiscal year 2018.

OPM’s security problems are nothing new. A security audit in late October from OPM’s Office of the Inspector General mirrors GAO’s concerns. The audit found that IT operations are “inappropriately decentralized” and that while procedures and policies are documented, they are not consistently implemented.

IN THEIR DEFENSE, IT’S ONLY BEEN THREE YEARS — The Pentagon hasn’t fully implemented all its requirements under the 2015 cybersecurity information sharing law, according to an inspector general report out Tuesday. The biggest barrier, the IG found, is that DoD’s chief information officer didn’t issue a policy on implementing the law. “As a result, the DoD limited its ability to gain a more complete understanding of cybersecurity threats since it did not fully leverage the collective knowledge and capabilities of sharing entities, or disseminate internally generated cyber threat indicators and defensive measures with other Federal and non‑Federal entities,” the report found. There were also problems with sub-agencies implementing the law and verifying security clearances.

RECENTLY ON PRO CYBERSECURITY — Chinese hackers are borrowing techniques from one of Russia’s most infamous hacking groups, according to Recorded Future. … A senior DoD official said Russian and Chinese cyberattacks on defense suppliers is one of the Pentagon’s biggest problems. … China contends that a U.S. ban on chipmaker Jinhau violates World Trade Organization rules. … Incoming House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff called on acting Attorney General Mark Whitaker to recuse himself from special counsel Robert Mueller’s probe, and warned that Democrats would be watching him.

TWEET OF THE DAY — *somber music plays*

REPORT WATCH

— Sophisticated bad bots used in cyberattacks make up 44 percent of all traffic on airline websites, mobile apps and application programming interfaces, according to research out today from Distil Networks. That’s nearly double the rate across all industries.

— LastPass ranked Wayfair the naughtiest online retailer when it comes to security and Apple the nicest in a report out today.

QUICK BYTES

— Why the Georgia runoff for secretary of state is important for election security. Intercept

— The RSA Conference released a new diversity initiative that bans all-male panels.

— Germany might exclude Chinese firms like Huawei from its 5G buildup out of national security concerns. Reuters

— The Foundation for Defense of Democracies hosted a tabletop cyber exercise for private sector and government officials with the scenario of a cross-sector crisis. CyberScoop

— Also, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency hosted an exercise on the grid going down. Nextgov

— The New York Times has a video series on fake news.

— “That Domain You Forgot to Renew? Yeah, it’s Now Stealing Credit Cards.” Krebs on Security

— Imperva researchers found a Facebook bug, since patched. ZDNet

— Microsoft patched a zero day across several products. Threatpost

— “Inside the Messy, Dark Side of Nintendo Switch Piracy.” Motherboard

That’s all for today.

Stay in touch with the whole team: Mike Farrell (mfarrell@politico.com, @mikebfarrell); Eric Geller (egeller@politico.com, @ericgeller); Martin Matishak (mmatishak@politico.com, @martinmatishak) and Tim Starks (tstarks@politico.com, @timstarks).

title: Immigrant families dropping from SNAP
description: ERS, NIFA relocation critics eye appropriations rider — Oyster shortages in the Gulf — Trade meetings on deck
content: With help from Helena Bottemiller Evich, Sarah Zimmerman, Nancy Cook, Liz Crampton and Catherine Boudreau Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access… [+12677 chars]
fulltext:
Immigrant families dropping from SNAP

With help from Helena Bottemiller Evich, Sarah Zimmerman, Nancy Cook, Liz Crampton and Catherine Boudreau

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Agriculture is published weekdays at 10 a.m. POLITICO Pro Agriculture subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 6 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

Story Continued Below

IN THE HOPPER: New data from health researchers shows that immigrants are dropping out of SNAP over fears about the Trump administration’s immigration policies, as Pro Ag reported earlier this year. Participation among eligible immigrant households was down about 10 percentage points over the first half of 2018.

— ERS, NIFA relocation watch: Critics of USDA’s plans to relocate two research agencies out of D.C. next year are calling for a special provision in an upcoming spending bill to put the moves on hold.

— The oyster industry is dealing with severe shortages in the Gulf of Mexico. Alabama called off its oyster harvesting season, Gulf states are using oil spill settlement funds to rebuild oyster habitats, and the Supreme Court is even weighing in.

IMMIGRANT FAMILIES DROP FROM SNAP: Remember all those anecdotal reports about immigrants dropping out of SNAP over fears about the current administration’s immigration policies and rhetoric? They may be indicative of a larger national trend, according to preliminary data released this week.

Drop off: Immigrant households legally eligible for food-stamp benefits stopped participating in the program at a higher-than-normal rate in the first half of this year, the data show.

First dive: The data is the first broad look at Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program participation declines among immigrants, surveying more than 35,000 mothers across five U.S. cities. It found that participation dropped by nearly 10 percentage points in the first half of 2018 for immigrant households that are eligible for the program and have been in the U.S. less than five years — compared with a participation rate of 43 percent from 2007 to 2017.

— The study seems to confirm months of anecdotal reports, from New York to San Antonio, Texas, that widespread fear in immigrant communities has had a chilling effect on participation in SNAP and other government aid programs like WIC, a federal nutrition program aimed at pregnant women and children.

— “We were hearing the anecdotal reports of people dropping out of SNAP and WIC, so we started looking at our data to see if that was true among the families we interview,” said Allison Bovell-Ammon, lead researcher and deputy director for policy strategy at Boston Medical Center’s Children’s HealthWatch, which conducted the study. More from our Helena Bottemiller Evich here.

HAPPY WEDNESDAY, NOV. 14! Welcome to Morning Ag, where your host wants to know how this Adams Morgan bar-goer’s Long Island Iced Tea was somehow tainted with “Yellow Death” cleaning fluid... Have any news or tips? Send ‘em to rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon, and follow the whole team @Morning_Ag.

COFFEE AND CONVERSATION: What do the midterm elections mean for U.S.-Canada relations? Join our Pro Canada colleagues, POLITICO Senior Politics Editor Charlie Mahtesian and the Nelson Mullins law firm for a breakfast briefing Thursday to find out. Kicking things off will be David Wilkins, former U.S. Ambassador to Canada and a Nelson Mullins partner. Get the details and sign up.

CRITICS OF ERS, NIFA MOVES EYE AG APPROPRIATIONS RIDER: The debate over a final fiscal 2019 Agriculture-FDA spending bill could include a battle over Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue’s plans to relocate the Economic Research Service and National Institute of Food and Agriculture out of Washington next year.

Dozens of public health, agriculture and research groups are pushing House and Senate appropriators to include a provision in the upcoming spending measure that would delay the move until an independent cost-benefit study is conducted and public hearings are held, Pro Ag’s Catherine Boudreau reports.

— USDA’s Inspector General is currently reviewing whether the department has the authority to move the agencies and if proper procedures were followed.

— Congress has until Dec. 7 to pass the seven remaining fiscal 2019 appropriations bills, including the Agriculture-FDA measure. (Of course, it can always extend that deadline by passing another short-term stopgap.)

Rep. Sanford Bishop (D-Ga.), who is in line to become chairman of the Appropriations Agriculture-FDA subpanel, told Pro Ag last month that appropriators were thinking about taking some sort of action on the ERS and NIFA plans: “We’re certainly looking at that and considering it.”

OYSTER SHORTAGES IN THE GULF: The oyster industry is facing severe shortages in the Gulf of Mexico, according to a report released today from The Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit group. The oyster population has declined by about 85 percent in the Gulf region, which leads the nation in commercial production.

The situation has become so grave that Alabama for the first time called off its oyster harvesting season due to scarcity. Officials are under pressure to balance protecting oysters as a commodity and as part of a habitat — the shellfish are integral to the survival of other marine wildlife.

“It’s only getting worse,” said Seth Blitch, the Nature Conservancy’s director of coastal and marine conservation in Louisiana. “These states are faced with trying to maintain stocks so there is a commercial harvest while trying to maintain natural resources, too.”

Where have all the oysters gone? The shortages, researchers say, aren’t so much about water quality as they are about water quantity. Imbalances of freshwater caused by droughts, hurricanes and other factors have decimated ecosystems and harvests.

The fight over freshwater access for oysters has even made its way to the Supreme Court — Florida and Georgia have been locked in a decadeslong battle over water access. In June, a divided court gave the Sunshine State another chance to prove Georgia was harming its oyster habitat by consuming too much water from the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River basin.

— The case, which has been sent back to a court-appointed special master for a final decision, could foreshadow how courts will play a role juggling water usage between humans and wildlife.

How to rebuild: States are tapping into their funds from the 2010 BP oil spill settlement reserved solely for oyster restoration. Texas, for example, announced today that it’s using $5 million of those funds to build an artificial reef that can be used for both restoration and harvesting.

TRADE MEETINGS ON DECK: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström will meet today in D.C. to continue laying the groundwork ahead of formal bilateral negotiations starting as soon as mid-January.

European nations are considering ramping up their purchases of U.S. biofuel ingredients like rapeseed, our POLITICO Pro Europe colleagues reported this week — a potential olive branch for American farmers that might help the EU keep broader agricultural issues out of the upcoming trade talks.

But President Donald Trump wasn’t exactly feeling the love Tuesday morning, when he targeted France with a tweetstorm including a gripe about French wine tariffs. He’s set to meet with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker at the G-20 gathering this month in Buenos Aires.

Main event: He’ll also join Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G-20 for a highly anticipated face-to-face discussion on trade (and other issues). Our colleagues on the POLITICO White House team tell MA that U.S. Ambassador to China Terry Branstad met with Trump in D.C. last Thursday to go over plans for the meeting with Xi. (Lighthizer, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and White House chief of staff John Kelly were also there.)

Listen up: Pro Trade’s Doug Palmer joins the POLITICO Money podcast to explain how the trade feud with China could go from bad to worse, and fast. Plug in your headphones and check it out here.

ROW CROPS

— Denham defeated in House race: House Ag member Jeff Denham(R-Calif.) was defeated by Democrat Josh Harder in the Central Valley district. Denham’s loss comes despite a late campaign boost from Trump, who delivered Republicans in the farmland region a major win on all-important water policy. Here’s more on the final result.

— Anti-pesticide groups oppose Hutchins’ nomination: More than 245 groups against the broad use of pesticides are opposing Scott Hutchins’ nomination as USDA chief scientist because they say his ties to Corteva Agriscience, a division of DowDuPont, “present serious conflicts of interest that will undoubtedly affect his ability” to serve in the role if confirmed by the Senate. You can find the letter here.

— Atrazine levels widespread in corn belt water sources: The Environmental Working Group today released a new analysis of drinking water contaminated by the weedkiller atrazine in corn-growing regions. EWG found that potentially harmful levels of the herbicide have been detected in drinking water for nearly 30 million Americans across 28 states. The group previously released a tap water quality database as part of its efforts to raise attention about agriculture’s impact on water quality in rural areas.

— Immigrant ag workers still reeling from Hurricane Florence: Undocumented laborers in North Carolina, fearing possible deportation, have avoided seeking disaster assistance after the storm caused severe flooding in the state’s major pork producing regions. Civil Eats has the story.

— Cotton sector to adopt sustainability metrics: Cotton Council International this week announced plans for an integrated data collection, measurement and verification process that will track the environmental impact of U.S. cotton production to help ensure the industry is meeting its 2025 sustainability goals. The details of the U.S. Cotton Trust Protocol are still being finalized, but a pilot project will launch in 2019 and full implementation is expected for the 2020 crop year. Read more here.

— Green group partners with corn growers: The National Corn Growers Association and Environmental Defense Fund in a new partnership being announced today plan to focus on metrics to track progress on practices designed to improve water quality, soil health and reduce greenhouse gas emissions on American farms, while promoting profitability. Beyond data collection, the two groups also will work together on advocating for voluntary conservation programs with measurable outcomes.

— An orange forecast: Over the next three years, Florida orange production is expected to drop as old groves are replaced and new ones start to bear fruit — continuing a steady decline over the last two decades largely due to citrus greening disease, according to a new report by CoBank, a top lender to rural agribusinesses, cooperatives and utilities. Imports of orange juice from Brazil are on track to increase to meet U.S. demand.

— How dicamba drift came to be: Reveal from the Center for Investigative Reporting and the Food & Environment Reporting Network did a deep dive on the history of dicamba and EPA’s recent decision to reauthorize the controversial pesticide for two years, despite some scientists warning of continued unintended damage to crops.

THAT’S ALL FOR MA! Same time, same place tomorrow. In the meantime, drop us a line: cboudreau@politico.com and @ceboudreau; rmccrimmon@politico.com and @ryanmccrimmon; hbottemiller@politico.com and @hbottemiller; lcrampton@politico.com and @liz_crampton; jlauinger@politico.com and @jmlauinger; and pjoshi@politico.com and @pjoshiny.

You can also follow @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Ag on Twitter.

content: Thomas Homan (R) is being considered for the role along with U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan, TSA Administrator David Pekoske, and Maj. Gen. Vincent Coglianese. | Kevin Dietsch-Pool/Getty Images The former Department of Homelan… [+2309 chars]

Tom Homan (right) is being considered for the role along with U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan, TSA Administrator David Pekoske, and Maj. Gen. Vincent Coglianese. | Kevin Dietsch-Pool/Getty Images White House Former acting ICE director on possible DHS job: 'We'll see what happens'

The former Department of Homeland Security official under consideration to be its next secretary offered a defense on Wednesday morning of the woman he could succeed, Kirstjen Nielsen, and did not let on whether the president had approached him about the job.

Tom Homan, the former acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, told Fox News that “I won't speculate what the president will do,” but praised Nielsen as a “strong secretary” and said she was succeeding in a difficult job. Homan did allow that the president could let her go at any time he likes.

Story Continued Below

“It’s a 24/7/365 job,” Homan said. “Fifty percent of America hates you 100 percent of the time, you can't win on this topic because it is so divisive.”

POLITICO reported Tuesday that Homan, who is now a contributor at Fox News, won Trump’s affection as a tough talking immigration hard-liner in his interim role at ICE and with his cable news defenses of Trump’s border policies. Homan said earlier this year that he delayed his retirement as acting director on Trump's request.

Homan is being considered for the role along with U.S. Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan, TSA Administrator David Pekoske, and Maj. Gen. Vincent Coglianese, who currently runs the Marine Corps Installations Command.

The president has reportedly long sought to get rid of Nielsen, whom he perceives as weak on border security. Talk of an end to her tenure with the Trump administration has escalated this week, following last week’s midterms that put Democrats in control of the House.

Homan on Wednesday cited POLITICO’s reporting but didn’t say whether he’d heard from Trump.

“I read the same story. We will see what happens,” he said, adding that “we need to support [Nielsen] until the decision is made.”

Homan also claimed Wednesday that though pushback from “Fox News, and myself, and the president” had made Democrats backpedal on threats to abolish ICE, under a Democratic House majority, the immigration enforcement agency would be in a “tough spot” because “they’re gonna strangle them on funding.”

BLUE WAVE grows: HARDER beats DENHAM -- PORTER pulls ahead of WALTERS in CA-45 -- THURMOND’s lead over TUCK grows -- ZINKE to join Brown in FIRE zone tour

THE BUZZ: JEREMY’s TAKE -- California Democrats and their allies saw their odds of claiming an across-the-board victory in this election jump Tuesday night.

-- BLUE WAVE ROLLING: Democratic candidates have already retained the governor’s mansion, reclaimed a two-thirds supermajority in the state Legislature and picked up at least four GOP House seats, with Democrat Josh Harder officially defeating Rep. Jeff Denham Tuesday night, and Democrat Katie Porter vaulting over Rep. Mimi Walters after closing in for days. Porter carved out a 261-vote lead.

Story Continued Below

-- THE BIG ENCHILADA: But the exorbitant state superintendent of public instruction race has remained the wild card. It’s nominally a nonpartisan race, but it’s no secret which candidate California Democrats prefer: The California Teachers Association, that steadfast liberal ally, and the California Democratic Party have invested millions in pushing state Assemblyman Tony Thurmond over the top, while Sen. Kamala Harris and now-Gov.-elect Gavin Newsom boosted Thurmond in campaign ads and appearances. They’re all seeking to counteract the millions that have flowed from charter school allies to back Marshall Tuck.

-- A protracted deficit for Thurmond in the days after the election suggested a rare defeat for the CTA might be coming. But after Thurmond went from trailing to a vanishingly tiny statistical margin — he and Tuck were at one point locked in a dead heat Tuesday — his lead jumped to well over 60,000 votes on the strength of a late update. With a mountain of ballots left to count — keep in mind Tuck was up by tens of thousands just days ago — this one bears watching.

-- ONE MORE HOTSPOT: Also worth keeping an eye on: the 16th state Assembly District, where longstanding efforts to topple the Bay Area’s sole Republican lawmaker could come to fruition. State Assemblywoman Catharine Baker was clinging to a 339 vote lead over Democratic challenger Rebecca Bauer-Kahan as of Tuesday night. Democrats have their two-thirds edge in the Assembly regardless, but knocking out Baker would still be a significant victory.

BUENOS DÍAS, Good Wednesday morning. President Donald Trump hasn’t made it to California, but he’s sending his interior secretary today. Fires still rage.

QUOTE OF THE DAY: “Don’t touch the bear. Keep your hands off the bear.” -- Gov.-elect Gavin Newsom, at a press conference with Gov. Jerry Brown, on lessons learned about the state icon outside the governor’s office.

-- TWEET OF THE DAY: Gavin Newsom @GavinNewsom: “Spent my morning soaking in the wisdom of @JerryBrownGov. Feeling humbled, excited, and ready to get to work!” With pix.

-- Where’s Jerry? Gov. Jerry Brown will survey wildfire damage with the U.S. Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke, FEMA Administrator Brock Long, and leaders of the Governor's’ Office of Emergency Services Wednesday. They will later hold a media briefing at the Incident Command Post in Chico, California. Details.

-- Where’s Gavin? Nothing official announced.

CALIFORNIA ON FIRE

ZINKE LINE: While Trump continues to face criticism for not yet surveying California fire damage, he’s dispatching a deputy: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke will be visiting the area devastated by the deadliest-in-California-history Camp Fire today. Zinke has channeled his boss in blaming California’s fires on “environmental terrorist groups” — POLITICO’s Jeremy B. White will be on the scene today and relay his latest thoughts.

-- FIRED UP: Republican state Sen. John Moorlach, in a blog post, argues that Gov. Jerry Brown had a big chance to push for fire prevention in his bill, SB1463 — and vetoed it. “I thought the adventure with my bill to address electric line-caused conflagrations in wildfire zones with SB 1463 (2016) had run its course.” Read it here.

-- RED AND BLUE POLITICS: “For Trump, even disaster response is colored in red and blue” by WaPo’s Matt Viser and Seung Min Kim: “A president who prizes and craves loyalty more than any other attribute, Trump has divided states into ones that voted for him and the ones that didn’t, and found that last group wanting. In California, that has meant state officials are having to fight not only killer fires but also the combustible rhetoric coming from Oval Office.” Story .

-- MORNING UPDATE: "Wildfire death toll rises as search for missing continues,'' by AP's Martha Mendoza and Gillian Flaccus: "Authorities on Tuesday reported six more fatalities from the Northern California blaze, bringing the total number of dead so far to 48. title: Federal prosecutors reviewing altered election documents tied to Florida Democrats
description: The Florida Department of State says the concerns can be tied to the Florida Democratic Party.
content: Broward County, which emerged as the epicenter of controversy as three statewide races and three local legislative races went into recounts following the Nov. 6 elections, was one of the counties mentioned in affidavits released Tuesday. | AP Photo/Brynn Ande… [+4469 chars]
fulltext:
Broward County, which emerged as the epicenter of controversy as three statewide races and three local legislative races went into recounts following the Nov. 6 elections, was one of the counties mentioned in affidavits released Tuesday. | AP Photo/Brynn Anderson Federal prosecutors reviewing altered election documents tied to Florida Democrats

TALLAHASSEE — The Florida Department of State last week asked federal prosecutors to investigate dates that were changed on official state election documents, the first voting “irregularities” it has flagged in the wake of the 2018 elections.

The concerns, which the department says can be tied to the Florida Democratic Party, center around date changes on forms used to fix vote-by-mail ballots sent with incorrect or missing information. Known as “cure affidavits,” those documents used to fix mail ballots were due no later than 5 p.m. on Nov. 5 — the day before the election. But affidavits released on Tuesday by the DOS show that documents from four different counties said the ballots could be returned by 5 p.m. on Thursday, which is not accurate.

Story Continued Below

Audio of a Florida Democratic Party caller leaving a voicemail message asking a Palm Beach County voter to fix their vote by mail ballot after Election Day, which is not allowed, was also sent to POLITICO separately. It was not part of the information turned over to federal prosecutors.

Among the counties in question is Broward, which emerged as the epicenter of controversy as three statewide races and three local legislative races went into recounts following the Nov. 6 elections. Republicans have pointed to embattled Broward Elections chief Brenda Snipes' record of past election gaffes in arguing that the largely Democratic country is tilted against them — perhaps fraudulently so.

DOS officials have repeatedly told the media that the monitors they sent to Broward County saw no election fraud. It wasn't until Tuesday that the office revealed publicly that it had turned over information to federal prosecutors.

The information was sent on Nov. 9 by Bradley McVay, DOS’ interim general counsel, who asked that the altered dates be investigated.

“Altering a form in a manner that provides the incorrect date for a voter to cure a defect … imposes a burden on the voter significant enough to frustrate the voter’s ability to vote,” McVay wrote in a letter that was sent Nov. 9 and released publicly on Tuesday. The letter was sent to U.S. Attorneys Christopher P. Canova of the Northern District of Florida, Maria Chapa Lopez of the Middle District of Florida and Ariana Fajardo Orshan in the Southern District of Florida.

The records released by DOS, which is part of Gov. Rick Scott’s administration, point the finger at the Florida Democratic Party. Political parties can get daily lists of people who had their mail-in ballots rejected. Political parties — or anyone else — can also get the publicly available cure affidavits and send them to voters who had a mail-in ballot rejected to encourage them to fix the ballots.

In an email chain released as part of the Department of State's Tuesday document dump, Citrus County Supervisor of Elections Susan Gill last week told DOS officials that a voter who received one of the cure affidavits with the wrong date had also received a call from a number identified as the Tallahassee office of the Florida Democratic Party, an indication the party was reaching out about her vote by mail ballot.

"When I called it, it is the Democratic Party of Florida," she said in a Nov. 8 email to DOS officials.

She went on to write that she thinks the incorrect date was used because whoever sent the cure affidavit mixed up the deadline for cure affidavits with the deadline for provisional ballots. But, she said, "a bigger problem is the fact they actually changed one of the DOE forms."

That change to an official election form was what state officials turned over to federal prosecutors.

Another email included in the DOS document dump included correspondence from Okaloosa County Supervisor of Elections Paul Lux, who also said he believed the affidavits were from the Florida Democratic Party.

"Please pass the word to the FDP that they can't arbitrarily add their own deadline to your form or VBM cures!!" Lux emailed DOS officials on Nov. 9. "This is crazy!"

In a Tuesday interview with POLITICO, Lux said he received an email from someone sending a cure affidavit marked with the wrong date that included a Florida Democratic Party email address. The email does contain the email address votes@FloridaDems.org, which is associated with the party.

Caroline Rowland, an FDP spokesperson, brushed off the issue, saying the Scott administration’s election office was drumming it up as a distraction.

"The courts have already forced Rick Scott to drop a lawsuit after false claims of fraud, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement rejected his desperate attempts to interfere with the important work of counting ballots,” she said in an email. “Now, Scott is once again trying to divert attention and resources from a smooth and successful recount."

title: Jordan touts Freedom Caucus bona fides in GOP leadership bid
description: He said that the GOP lost its majority in the House because it failed to match the "intensity" of President Donald Trump.
content: President Donald Trump is reportedly pushing House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy to make Rep. Jim Jordan the ranking member on the House Judiciary Committee. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Rep. Jim Jordan, the former chairman of the House Freedom Caucus who is run… [+2581 chars]
fulltext:
President Donald Trump is reportedly pushing House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy to make Rep. Jim Jordan the ranking member on the House Judiciary Committee. | Alex Wong/Getty Images Congress Jordan touts Freedom Caucus bona fides in GOP leadership bid

Rep. Jim Jordan, the former chairman of the House Freedom Caucus who is running to be the next House Republican leader, said Wednesday that the GOP lost its majority in the House because it failed to match the "intensity" of President Donald Trump.

Jordan (R-Ohio), widely considered to be the underdog candidate against Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) in Wednesday's leadership elections, held up his bona fides as a leader of the arch-conservative Freedom Caucus as one of his top qualifications for the job of GOP leader.

Story Continued Below

“Two years ago the American people elected President Trump to come to this town to shake it up and he's done just that. But I don't think they've seen this same intensity from House Republicans,” he said in an interview on Fox News’ “Fox & Friends.”

Jordan cited conservative priorities like repealing the Affordable Care Act, building Trump's long-promised wall along the southern border and overhauling welfare programs as areas where Republicans came up short, despite control of both houses of Congress and the White House. Those failures, he said were the reason for Republicans’ trouncing on Election Day, when they lost at least 34 seats.

COUNTDOWN TO 2020 The race for 2020 starts now. Stay in the know. Follow our presidential election coverage. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

“I think that was the biggest problem we had, because we lost so many races by the slimmest of margins,” he said. “If we get the things done that we told them we were going to do, I think we win many of those races and we would have stayed in the majority.”

The Ohio Republican's comments come in the wake of behind-the-scenes efforts by Trump to bolster Jordan's standing within the House, reportedly pushing House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.), the odds-on favorite to be minority leader in the next Congress, to make Jordan the ranking member on the House Judiciary Committee.

Jordan argued Wednesday that the Freedom Caucus’ reputation for punching back at leadership will make for a useful quality in what Jordan said would be a hostile, Democrat-controlled chamber, a situation many House Republicans have not experienced.

“We got to understand the environment we're going into is something we've never seen,” he said, ticking off a list of likely Democratic committee chairs. “We’re gonna have to be to be prepared with the right attitude to come to this town to fight every single minute of every single day defending the truth as they're attacking everybody. That's the environment we're going into.”

fulltext:
MENDOZA makes it official — DRAMA at Springfield presser — ETHICS about diversion programs Presented by the Illinois Car Sharing Coalition

Good Wednesday morning, Illinois. Michelle Obama tells sold-out United Center crowd and makes a dig at Trump: Trib was there.

THE BUZZ

Susana Mendoza made it official Tuesday after weeks of playing coy: She’s running for mayor. And with her entrance in the campaign, it’s a real race. Expect it to be fierce.

Story Continued Below

Mendoza, who just won re-election as state comptroller, has long portrayed herself as a government watchdog and proponent of transparency in government. Now she’s out with her mayoral campaign video—the real video—announcing her run and telling her personal story. How she grew up in the Little Village neighborhood, how her family moved away after gun violence on her block, and how she returned to the neighborhood. “Safe neighborhoods, good schools, high property taxes, they’re not just issues to me,” Mendoza says in the video. “I live them, too.”

It’s a strong message, but will it give her the oomph she needs to surpass others hoping to stand out in the race?

Mendoza, 46, brings youthfulness to the campaign, but also experience — she‘s previously served in the state legislature and as city clerk. In that position she’s credited with modernizing the sticker program that once had residents waiting in line for hours. And she’s experienced at running a political campaign. Mendoza already has a team out gathering the required signatures needed to get on the ballot.

Her fluent Spanish could be a force in bringing out Latino voters.

With her entry into the campaign, the candidate playing field is almost set. We say almost because there are still a few weeks before we know who makes it on the ballot. Political insiders expect unions to step forward and commit to a candidate. So far, for example, only SEIU has committed to Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle, Mendoza’s chief competitor in the race.

Related:

— LaRaviere drops out of the mayor’s race with a parting shot at Kanye and Enyia, reports Sun-Times’ Fran Spielman: “If you campaign to launch a war on corruption — but then look the other way in order to accept support from questionable sources — then you’ve taken the first step toward becoming the corruption you once sought to end.” Story here

MORE BUZZ

State lawmakers are in Springfield this week to consider overriding bills that Gov. Bruce Rauner vetoed before the midterms. Tuesday was a lot of procedural work with little action. But there was some political theater. It centered on a vetoed bill that calls for more regulation of “peer to peer” rental car companies. Those are businesses that allow individuals to rent out their own cars much the way home owners rent out their homes. A group of D’s and R’s gathered with Hertz and other rental-car company officials at a press conference calling for an override. They say it’s necessary because car owners don’t always adhere to safety regulations. The bill would require that and would make sure car owners pay their fair share of taxes at airports, just the way rental car companies do.

After the press conference, a man stood up saying he represents Turo, one of the companies that a company that manages those car rentals. It was a dramatic move that got him kicked out of the room since he didn’t reserve it. More interesting, he announced his name: Lou Bertuca. Yeah that Lou Bertuca, the former aide to Gov. Pat Quinn. Bertuca now lives in California and oversees government relations for Turo. In the hallway, he told reporters the bill would unfairly tax individuals trying to make a living.

We’ll see what lawmakers think. The bill’s sponsor, Tony Munoz, was working the state Senate floor Tuesday afternoon to gather votes for an override.

Related:

— Democrats and Republicans re-elected their top leaders last night during private gatherings in Springfield. Bill Brady was elected GOP leader of the state Senate, and Jim Durkin was elected GOP House leader. The Senate Democratic Caucus re-elected John Cullerton as Senate president—a position he’s held for a decade. No word on whether Mike Madigan was elected to lead House Dems, but you can count on it happening.

CAMPAIGNS

— Lakeview resident Austin Baidas officially launches his campaign for alderman of the 44th Ward today. He's challenging 15-year incumbent Tom Tunney. Baidas is a businessman who previously served as the state's associate budget director under former Governor Pat Quinn and worked in the Obama Administration focusing on pipeline pipeline and hazardous material and safety. Baidas has more than $350,000 in his campaign fund.

— Chance the Rapper is hosting a political fundraiser for mayoral candidate Amara Enyia at the Chicago Chop House. Billed as “an intimate evening with one of Chicago’s biggest musical stars,” the event takes place tonight from 8 p.m. to midnight at the restaurant at 60 W. Ontario Street. Price ranges from $100 per person, to attend cocktail party, up to $5,000—which gets you dinner, photo and after party with Chance and Enyia. Details here

CHICAGO

— What sunk Chicago in Amazon's eyes? Emanuel offers a hint, by Crain’s’ Greg Hinz: “Let me put it this way,” Mayor Rahm Emanuel said when asked if Illinois' budget, infrastructure and tax issues were factors in Amazon's decision to bypass Chicago for its second headquarters. “I know what Chicago has to offer, and we put our best foot forward.” Story here

The Reader spoke with teenage girls participating in two Chicago programs that are working to combat the problem. Story here

— Cook County State’s Attorney Kim Foxx met with Illinois Retailers Association officials Tuesday to talk about concerns some retailers have about charging shoplifters with misdemeanors. Previously, shoplifting was a felony. Some retailers blame emboldened shoplifters for a rise in crime—and loss of business. The discussion has come up as Target plans to close two stores on the South Side. Foxx says there’s data to prove that the charging changes aren’t the issue. Also, underperforming stores on the South Side have no greater incidents of retail theft than the downtown stores, she says.

STATE

— Diversion programs say they offer a path away from court, but critics say the tolls are hefty, by Rebecca Burns for ProPublica Illinois: "Diversion programs like the one in Kankakee County, which launched last year, raise a host of legal and ethical questions, including whether they create an uneven playing field for criminal defendants, with those able to pay gaining an advantage over those who cannot, and whether they create financial incentives for prosecutors to dispose of cases in ways they might not otherwise." Story here

— Michael Milkie, CEO of the Noble Network of charter schools announced Tuesday that he will retire at the end of the calendar year. Chalkbeat has the story here

— Report says Illinois higher education is separate but unequal, by Illinois News Connection: Black students are severely underrepresented in Illinois schools, according to a report from the Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce: Despite representing 18 percent of the college-age population, only about 9 out of every 100 Illinois selective public college freshmen are black, the report found. Story here

— A Lincoln impersonator kicked off the state General Assembly’s fall veto session when he appeared before the House tourism committee along with officials of the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum Foundation. It was all part of an attempt to get state funds to help preserve artifacts connected to the 16th president and to remind state lawmakers that Lincoln’s legacy should extend beyond the controversial stovepipe hat. Sun-Times’ Alexandra Arriaga has the story here

DELEGATION

Congressman Brad Schneider (IL-10) is throwing his support for Nancy Pelosi's campaign for U.S. House speaker: “In this critical moment, given both the challenges and the opportunities before us, I believe there is no one better equipped to lead us forward than Nancy Pelosi,” Schneider said in a statement.

Valerie Jarrett echoed that. The former aide to President Barack Obama wrote an op-ed for CNN that described Pelosi as “House Democrats' toughest leader.” Jarrett credits her with passing the Affordable Care Act, pushing for diversity in Congress and staying above the fray even when “sexist attacks” were leveled at her. Kudlow vs. Navarro

Editor's Note: This edition of Free Morning Money is published weekdays at 8 a.m. POLITICO Pro Financial Services subscribers hold exclusive early access to the newsletter each morning at 5:15 a.m. To learn more about POLITICO Pro's comprehensive policy intelligence coverage, policy tools and services, click here.

KUDLOW VS NAVARRO BLOWS UP — Until now, NEC Director Larry Kudlow has approached the perennial free traders vs. nationalists fight inside the White House very differently than his predecessor Gary Cohn. Cohn, known for years as a Wall Street tough guy, regularly displayed his disdain for protectionist trade adviser Peter Navarro, moving to reduce Navarro’s role and keeping him out of meetings. Kudlow, genteel and gregarious by nature, has tried to stay on good terms with Navarro and keep policy disputes civil and inside the building.

Story Continued Below

That changed on Tuesday with Kudlow publicly rebuking Navarro during a CNBC interview over Navarro’s deeply hawkish China speech on Friday. The vibe coming out of the White House — partly in response to market declines — has been that progress is being made with China and that the G-20 meeting could pave the way for a deal. Navarro stomped all over that. And Kudlow was unhappy.

And he spoke in ways that had to have approval from the president. Kudlow and Trump kibitz regularly in person and by phone and it’s very difficult to imagine that the NEC director spoke this way about Navarro without approval from the president. This matters because among the most consequential economic decisions facing the White House right now is whether to enter into a full-blown trade war with China.

Here’s what Kudlow said: “Look, Peter Navarro is a friend of mine, truly. We’ve known each other for 20 years, but he was not speaking for the president, nor was he speaking for the administration. His remarks were way off base. They were not authorized by anybody. I actually think he did the president a great disservice. Look, the president can talk to whomever he can talk to. He talks to people on Wall Street, yes. He talks to union leaders.

“I’ve been in some of those meetings. He talks to other outside advisers. He has every right to do so. And the president has said … that if there is a deal to be had with China, it’s a deal that has to be in American interests. So I think Peter very badly misspoke. He was freelancing and he’s not representing the president or the administration.”

WIN FOR THE FREE TRADERS (FOR NOW) — The White House meeting on Tuesday on auto tariffs concluded with an agreement not to move forward with the levies for now, according to a person familiar with the meeting. The Commerce Department will continue to work on a report about whether imported autos impact national security. Trump has been hot to slap the tariffs on for quite a while but the auto industry doesn’t want them. And markets don’t want them. And they would presumably complicate negotiations with the EU barring a blanket exemption. For now they will remain a threat in Trump’s back pocket.

CRUNCH TIME ON TRADE — In the latest POLITICO Money podcast, POLITICO senior trade reporter Doug Palmer explains the potential for Trump to hit over $500 billion in Chinese imports with tariffs as high as 25 percent over the coming months. Consumers would feel such tariffs immediately and quite painfully.

Trump is scheduled to sit down with Chinese premier Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 Summit at the end of the month in Buenos Aires, Argentina. Free traders inside the administration are hoping the bilateral talks forestall another round of tariffs and set up future negotiations.

But there is a raging battle going on inside the West Wing with Navarro trying to tamp down hopes for the talks and free-trade voices including Kudlow sounding hopeful. The fear among the free traders is that another big round of tariffs will drive up consumer prices, further impede American exporters – especially farmers – and slow down economic growth. Higher prices caused by tariffs could also push the Federal Reserve into more aggressive interest rate hikes to fight inflation.

FIRST LOOK: FREEDOM PARTNERS PRESS TRUMP/XI — In a letter going out this a.m., Americans for Prosperity, Freedom Partners, and The LIBRE Initiative press Trump and Xi to make progress at the G-20: “There is great urgency for the United States and China to come together and reach an agreement to eliminate tariffs and protectionist trade policies. The continued escalation of tariffs has come at significant cost to the global economy.

“It has harmed businesses, farmers, consumers, workers, and families worldwide, inflicting higher costs, lost jobs, and uncertainty. Fortunately, government leaders on both sides appear open to negotiations to drop tariffs in favor of a compromise that helps everyone.”

FHLB JOINGS PUSH TO REPLACE LIBOR — Our Victoria Guida: “The Federal Home Loan Banks on Tuesday became the latest major financial player to boost the effort to replace LIBOR, issuing $4 billion in debt tied to the Federal Reserve’s new alternative rate.

“The government-sponsored banks, which lend to thousands of financial institutions using funds raised by issuing debt, are hoping their move will add momentum to the push to wean the global economy off using the scandal-scarred London InterBank Offered Rate as a benchmark for interest rates.” Read more.

MORE WHITE HOUSE DRAMA— Our Christopher Cadelago and Nancy Cook on the latest in an unhappy White House: “Bottled-up hostility in … Trump’s administration flowed to the surface Tuesday, in a remarkable 12-hour period following an awkward midterm détente and tense presidential trip to Paris that he’s still seething over. ‘It’s like an episode of ‘Maury,’’ one former Trump aide observed to POLITICO as the spectacle unfolded. ‘The only thing that’s missing is a paternity test.’

“At the White House, Trump appeared poised to dismiss Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, a source of personal frustration for months over what he views as weak leadership on border security and other enforcement policies he’s sought to implement. The fresh round of backbiting and post-midterm turnover could also sweep out Trump’s chief of staff John Kelly, a close Nielsen ally, and see him replaced with Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff, Nick Ayers” Read more.

TRUMP RAGES AT THERESA MAY — WP’s Josh Dawsey and Philip Rucker: “As he jetted to Paris last Friday … Trump received a congratulatory phone call aboard Air Force One. British Prime Minister Theresa May was calling to celebrate the Republican Party’s wins in the midterm elections — never mind that Democrats seized control of the House — but her appeal to the American president’s vanity was met with an ornery outburst.

“Trump berated May for Britain not doing enough, in his assessment, to contain Iran. He questioned her over Brexit and complained about the trade deals he sees as unfair with European countries. May has endured Trump’s churlish temper before, but still her aides were shaken by his especially foul mood, according to U.S. and European officials briefed on the conversation.” Read more.

THE LIST OF THINGS ANGERING TRUMP — An incomplete tally: Markets are a mess; Growth appears to be slowing; Democrats now control the House and can investigate him; More House races continue to get called for Democrats and the GOP Senate performance looks less and less impressive; Rumors continue to swirl of potential Mueller indictments; Trump's Paris trip was widely panned as a disaster; His replacement Attorney General is mired in controversy; CNN is suing over the ouster of its reporter and looks likely to win. Are we missing anything?

GOOD WEDNESDAY MORNING — Thanks to all who turned out for the fantastic Women Rule event at S&P last night. Great energy and amazing questions. Email me at bwhite@politico.com and follow me on Twitter @morningmoneyben. Email Aubree Eliza Weaver at aweaver@politico.com and follow her on Twitter @AubreeEWeaver.

THIS MORNING ON POLITICO PRO FINANCIAL SERVICES — Patrick Temple-West on the new regulatory risks facing financial companies as they race to invest in artificial intelligence tools. To get Morning Money every day before 6 a.m., please contact Pro Services at (703) 341-4600 or info@politicopro.com.

DRIVING THE DAY— House Financial Services at 10:00 a.m. holds a hearing on bank regulation with Fed Vice Chair for Supervision Randy Quarles … Consumer Prices at 8:30 a.m. expected to rise 0.3 percent headline and 0.2 percent core … Fed Chair Jay Powell speaks at 6:15 p.m. at the Dallas Fed

ALSO TODAY — The National Association of Manufacturers hosts a briefing on the SEC's upcoming proxy roundtable from 3 p.m. – 4 p.m. in Rayburn 2219

STOCKS/OIL STILL UNDER PRESSURE — Reuters: “Oil prices struggled for traction on Wednesday after sinking on worries about weakening world demand and oversupply, while global shares sagged with slowing growth concerns overshadowing potential positives such as progress in the Brexit saga.

“U.S. crude futures dived 7 percent the previous day, suffering their biggest one-day loss in more than three years. … Brent had soared to a four-year high of $86.74 early in October as the market braced for U.S. sanctions on Iran, but prices have sunk nearly 25 percent since then.” Read more.

AMAZON GETS ROUGH REACTION — POLITICO’s Lorraine Woellert and Steven Overly: “Amazon’s triumphant announcement Tuesday of its moves into the Beltway and New York City called attention to an uncomfortable truth: The online juggernaut has fast become one of Washington’s most-scorned companies.

“Jeff Bezos’ company has soared as it has expanded into far-flung corners of the economy, from retail, drones and Hollywood movies to cloud computing and facial recognition — underscored by the billions of dollars in incentives that Virginia and New York agreed to lavish on Amazon to lure its two new headquarters sites. But its growing influence and power have also made it the target of lawmakers, regulators, labor unions and corporate rivals like Walmart, and even … Trump himself.” Read more.

BAD NEWS ON CAP-EX FROM TAX CUTS — POLITICO’s Toby Eckert for Pros: “Companies are using their windfall from recent tax cuts to pay down debt, while focusing less on acquisitions and capital expenditures, according to a new report by Moody's Investors Service.

“‘In the aftermath of tax overhaul we have seen a drastic change in company behavior, with companies moving from a net borrower to net payer position,’ said David Gonzales, Moody's vice president and senior accounting analyst, in a statement. ‘Prior to tax overhaul, the 100 companies we tracked were adding an annual average of $123 billion in additional total debt, but since the overhaul they have paid down $64 billion in total debt’ Companies are also continuing to boost shareholder returns, the report said.” Read more.

MARKETS

STOCKS’ REBOUND ATTEMPT FALTERS — WSJ’s David Hodari and Corrie Driebusch: “A steepening slide in oil prices dragged down U.S. stocks, scuttling major indexes’ earlier attempt to mount a rebound. … U.S. crude oil fell for its 12th consecutive session of losses on fears of oversupply and weakening demand. It has been a swift fall: On Oct. 3 oil prices settled at $76.41; they’re now 27 percent below that level. Energy stocks in the S&P 500 have been slower to react to the steep drop. Since the start of October they have fallen 14 percent, including Tuesday’s 2.4 percent decline.” Read more.

And is more trouble ahead? — CNBC’s Patti Domm and Gina Francolla: “Even as stocks seemed steadier on Tuesday after Monday's big sell-off, some charts still look very dicey to technical analysts, who warn of more possible losses to come.

“For instance, the S&P 500 index closed below its 200-day moving average, a key measure, on Tuesday for a second day, in a sign of a possible trend change. That moving average is no longer pointed upward and is descending, in another negative sign for analysts who follow the charts. And the small-cap Russell 2000 index looks to be heading for a scary negative chart pattern, called a ‘death cross.’” Read more.

GOLDMAN’S STOCK DECLINE LEAVES WALL STREET WONDERING — Bloomberg’s Claire Ballentine and Felice Maranz: “Goldman Sachs Group Inc.’s shares fell for a third day as analysts speculated on how long the pain will continue. The stock dropped 0.5 percent more on Tuesday as investors grappled with the potential fallout from the firm’s involvement in raising money for Malaysia’s scandal-plagued state investment company 1MDB earlier this decade. The shares’ three-day plunge was the worst since August 2011.

“The financial impact and reputational damage of the scandal are ‘nearly impossible to quantify at this point in time,’ Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Brian Kleinhanzl wrote in a note Tuesday. ‘The ultimate question is who knew what and when regarding 1MDB and that question remains open-ended for now.’” Read more.

FLY AROUND

AMAZON PICKS NEW YORK CITY, NORTHERN VIRGINIA FOR NEW HQ — Reuters’ Jeffrey Dastin and David Shepardson: “Amazon.com Inc picked America’s financial and political capitals for massive new offices on Tuesday, branching out from its home base in Seattle with plans to create more than 25,000 jobs in both New York City and an area just outside Washington, D.C.

“The world’s largest online retailer plans to spend $5 billion on the two new developments in Long Island City and Arlington, Virginia, and expects to get more than $2 billion in tax credits and incentives with plans to apply for more.” Read more.

MOST BANKS LEFT BUSINESS LENDING STANDARDS UNTOUCHED IN Q3 — WSJ’s Paul Kiernan: “Most banks in the U.S. left their standards for lending to businesses little changed in the third quarter, according to the Federal Reserve’s latest survey of senior loan officers. Of those that changed their business-lending standards, more eased than tightened, the Fed said Tuesday.

“More banks eased standards on commercial and industrial loans than tightened them in the third quarter, particularly in the case of large firms with more than $50 million in annual revenue, according to the survey, which was conducted in early October. The Fed’s senior-loan-officer opinion survey has, in the past, served as an early indicator when banks tended toward making riskier loans.” Read more.

BUDGET DEFICIT UP TO $100.5B IN OCTOBER — AP’s Martin Crutsinger: “The federal government recorded a deficit of $100.5 billion in October, a big increase from a year ago that was primarily caused by quirks in the calendar. The Treasury Department said Tuesday that the deficit shot up 59 percent from the same month a year ago. Last year’s October deficit was smaller because the government paid $48 billion in benefits in September because Oct. 1 fell on the weekend.

“The government has run a deficit in every October going back to the early 1950s. The new report begins a budget year in which the federal deficit is expected to soar above $1 trillion, reflecting in part the $1.5 trillion in tax cuts Congress approved last December.” Read more.

PELOSI LAUNCHES CHARM OFFENSIVE -- Trump meddles in minority leader race -- DENHAM LOSES -- Merkley seeks Booker law in Oregon

By Nolan D. McCaskill ( nmccaskill@politico.com or @NolanDMcCaskill )

With an assist from Burgess Everett and Elana Schor

Story Continued Below

PELOSI TARGETS INCOMING FRESHMEN -- House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) is running a charm offensive to win over incoming freshmen, an effort that includes private meetings, dinners with members-elect and their spouses, and the deployment of Democratic heavyweights. Pelosi made a surprise appearance at the Congressional Progressive Caucus’ freshman orientation Monday and held a reception Tuesday afternoon at an Italian restaurant by the D.C. waterfront. “On Wednesday, the members-elect will be introduced to their colleagues at a Democratic Caucus meeting, a lengthy process that will put them onstage with Pelosi,” Bres, Rachael and Kyle report.

“The California Democrat will follow that up with an appearance at the Congressional Black Caucus, a powerful faction inside the Democratic Caucus,” they continue. “Then, Pelosi will host a private dinner for members-elect and their spouses Wednesday evening in Statuary Hall, right off the House floor.” Democratic Party luminaries, including former Vice President Al Gore, former Secretary of State John Kerry and Govs. Andrew Cuomo of New York and Tom Wolf of Pennsylvania, are making calls on Pelosi’s behalf. Pelosi herself has also made calls -- and held private meetings -- to members-elect.

“It’s all part of the ‘Pelosi for Speaker’ blitz, with the California Democrat showing off every trick in her vast arsenal of persuasive tactics as she works to round up the votes she needs to win two upcoming votes: one inside the Democratic Caucus on Nov. 28, and the critical one on the House floor Jan. 3,” they write. “While Pelosi will easily get a majority inside the Democratic Caucus, how she handles that vote is crucial. Letting some members and members-elect vote against her so they can say they opposed her, for example, would then free them up to back her on the floor. That will set the stage for the run-up to the Jan. 3 vote, where the stakes will be far higher.” More: https://politi.co/2RUgPvH

Related: “Nine Democrats want promises from Pelosi in exchange for speaker votes,” by The Washington Post’s Mike DeBonis: https://wapo.st/2TalScG ; and “Anti-Pelosi Democrats Claim They Have Numbers to Block Her in Speaker Floor Vote,” from Roll Call’s Lindsey McPherson: http://bit.ly/2qL6Z3J

HOYER HAS THE VOTES -- House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) has already clinched enough votes to become majority leader in the next Congress. “Despite calls for new leadership, Hoyer has faced the least resistance among House Democrats’ big three,” Bres and I note. “He has the support of at least two-thirds of the incoming Democratic Caucus, according to a letter obtained by POLITICO.” More than 150 Democrats announced their support for Hoyer in a “Dear Colleague” letter Tuesday afternoon, casting him as the best person for the job. The diversity of the signatories, which range from progressives to Blue Dogs, highlights Hoyer’s broad support within the caucus. More: https://politi.co/2K44gLw

Related reads: “Left treads carefully as Dems taste power,” per Elana: https://politi.co/2DEqXFQ ; and “Will Dems work with us, or simply put partisan politics ahead of the country?” via Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.): https://fxn.ws/2QCe6Xj

CLYBURN WARNS OF DOG WHISTLES IN WHIP RACE -- Rep. James Clyburn (D-S.C.) is the only top Democrat who has a challenger for leadership in the next Congress: Rep. Diana DeGette (D-Colo.). But the assistant Democratic leader says detractors are using “dog whistles” to undermine his race. “Someone came to me over the weekend and told me that (they heard), when I was whip before, I was a figurehead,” Clyburn said. He dismissed that notion, saying, “Nothing could be further from the truth.” Clyburn, however, isn’t blaming his opponent for the attacks. And DeGette’s spokesman says the congresswoman “categorically and respectfully” denies using racially-charged talking points. More: http://bit.ly/2zRjvCJ

Related: “Why Young, Talented Democrats Flee the House,” by The Atlantic’s Elaina Plott: http://bit.ly/2OLcFEB

HAPPY WEDNESDAY! Thanks for reading Huddle, the play-by-play guide to all things Capitol Hill, on this Nov. 14.

TUESDAY’S MOST CLICKED: The Associated Press’ report on how Maine’s new ranked-choice voting is facing a test in the 2nd Congressional District race was the winner.

TRUMP MEDDLES IN GOP LEADERSHIP RACE -- President Donald Trump has urged House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) to cut a deal with Freedom Caucus co-founder Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), who is challenging McCarthy for minority leader in the next Congress. “It remains unclear what exactly the deal would entail,” Rachael, Bres and Kyle report. “The discussions between the president and McCarthy about Jordan, which took place last week, set off a round of speculation among lawmakers inside the Capitol that Trump may try to push Jordan to become the top Republican lawmaker on the House Judiciary Committee, a panel expected to launch an array of Democratic investigations against the president -- and possibly even an impeachment probe.”

Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski told MSNBC that Jordan will be the panel’s ranking member. Trump believes Jordan would be a ferocious defender, and the Ohio Republican wants the post. “But McCarthy does not have authority to unilaterally appoint a lawmaker to any ranking member position,” they note. “Rather, the decision is up to the Republican Steering Committee, a collection of members who do not like Jordan and may not take their cues from the White House.” More: https://politi.co/2PuBHwQ

Related read: “Stung by election losses, House GOP weighs leadership choice,” from The Associated Press’ Lisa Mscaro: http://bit.ly/2PXwb5j

SHUTDOWN WATCH -- The upcoming government funding fight will center on the president’s border wall and special counsel Robert Mueller. “Democrats said Tuesday they might insist that language protecting Mueller’s job security be included in a must-pass spending bill due by Dec. 7,” Burgess reports. “With Mueller’s probe on Russian interference in the 2016 election winding down and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) loath to bring up a standalone Mueller-protection bill, Democrats argue it could be their last chance to shield the special counsel from Trump. Meanwhile, the president and his GOP allies are asking for a significant funding boost for border security in order for Trump to sign the government spending bill.” Much more: https://politi.co/2QFnN7r

FIRST IN HUDDLE: NEW POLLING ON CRIMINAL JUSTICE BILL -- As the president nears a potential endorsement of bipartisan criminal justice legislation that’s been shepherded by Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and presidential son-in-law and adviser Jared Kushner, one of the leading groups backing the deal is coming out with new polling showing broad, aisle-crossing support for its core provisions.

The polling, released by the nonprofit Justice Action Network, was conducted by the GOP firm Public Opinion Strategies and shows 76 percent of voters agreeing that judges should be not be bound by mandatory minimum sentences for offenses they feel don’t merit such a harsh punishment. In addition, the polling showed 87 percent of voters agreeing on the ability of incarcerated individuals to get credits for good behavior as well as engaging in training and treatment programs.

COMMITTEE SHUFFLE -- Grassley is mulling whether to stay atop the Judiciary Committee or chair the Finance Committee. His decision “will have significant ramifications for his colleagues and for Congress as a whole,” Burgess writes. “Grassley has long said he would make his decision immediately after the midterms, presumably to see who captured the majority. But now he says he needs more time to talk to GOP senators that will be affected by his decision given the domino effect Grassley will produce either way.” He signaled he’ll make a decision within “a few days.”

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) would likely chair the Judiciary Committee if Grassley went to Finance, giving him authority to oversee the confirmation of a new attorney general nominee and conservative judges. But if Grassley stays, Sen. Mike Crapo (R-Idaho) would be in line to chair the Finance Committee, and Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.) would be favored to succeed Crapo as chair of the Banking Committee. “Sen. Roger Wicker (R-Miss.) is likely to be the new Commerce Committee chairman since current Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) is becoming party whip,” Burgess adds, “and Sen. Jim Risch (R-Idaho) is expected to take over at Senate Foreign Relations with the retirement of Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.).” More: https://politi.co/2zVfptk

DOWN GOES DENHAM -- Democrat Josh Harder has ousted Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.). Fellow California Republicans Steve Knight and Dana Rohrabacher were also defeated this month, and Democrats picked up an open seat held by outgoing Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.). “Two other California seats, both now held by Republicans, are still being counted: The 39th (an open seat formerly held by Ed Royce) and the 45th (now held by Mimi Walters),” POLITICO reports. “Overall, seven House districts remain uncalled throughout the nation, including one each in Georgia, Maine, New Jersey, Texas and Utah. Not counting those districts, Democrats hold an edge of 229-199 heading into the new session of Congress, a net gain of 34 seats.” More: https://politi.co/2za4GM1

Related: “Poliquin sues to stop ranked-choice count, saying process could be illegal,” via the Portland Press Herald’s Kevin Miller and Scott Thistle: http://bit.ly/2PqlYyJ

RETIREMENT WATCH -- Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) is already the subject of some steady rumors that he may not run for reelection in 2020. In an interview on Tuesday evening, Durbin gave nothing away but expects to quell the rumors soon enough. “I’ll make that decision public soon,” he said. “But I’m doing everything I can to get ready. I’m not going to announce any decision today.” Durbin, 73, has served in Congress since 1983, representing Illinois first in the House and then in the Senate.

Related read: “Kyl: No decision on how long to serve in Senate,” by Elana: https://politi.co/2DmoiQg ; and “Schumer sees Nelson victory after recount,” from Burgess: https://politi.co/2DGmzWE

2020 WATCH -- Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) is seeking the Cory Booker (D-N.J.) treatment. “Salem sources tell [Willamette Week] Merkley has quietly asked state legislators for a change in Oregon law so he can run for both president and the U.S. Senate in 2020,” Nigel Jaquiss reports. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy recently signed a bill allowing Booker to seek the Senate and White House simultaneously. “Merkley served as speaker of the Oregon House in 2007 and retains a reservoir of goodwill in that chamber,” Jaquiss adds. “He may face more resistance to changing the law in the Senate, where Democrats are more conservative.” More: http://bit.ly/2K7sRiI

Booker, meanwhile, told Yahoo Finance he’s considering a presidential run. Booker insisted he’s focused on his reelection to the Senate in 2020 but will consider a White House bid down the road. “Now is not the time to do that,” he said. “I’m running for reelection, but will I take some time over the coming months to consider it? I absolutely will.” More: https://yhoo.it/2qKh6px

Related: “Bloomberg charts aggressive timeline on 2020 bid,” via The Associated Press’ Steve Peoples: http://bit.ly/2z7oEqZ ; “New effort promises 1,000 trained Democratic staffers for 2020,” per Natasha Korecki: https://politi.co/2DE4Y1S

TRANSITIONS -- Thomas Clees is now vice president of public policy at the Recording Industry Association of America. He was previously a senior policy adviser and counsel for Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.).

Lewis H. Myers III is now director of operations for Del. Stacey Plaskett (D-V.I.). He was previously a scheduler for Rep. Norma Torres (D-Calif.).

Lizzie Litzow is joining FEMA as press secretary. She most recently was communications director for Rep. Michael McCaul (R-Texas).

Valeria Carranza is joining Montgomery County, Maryland, Councilmember-at-Large Evan Glass as chief of staff. She most recently was deputy chief of staff and legislative director for Rep. Adriano Espaillat (D-N.Y.).

TODAY IN CONGRESS -- The House gavels in at 12 p.m. with first and last votes expected between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m. Today’s agenda: http://bit.ly/2EsSWEM The Senate meets at 2 p.m. to resume consideration of Coast Guard reauthorization. At approximately 2:15 p.m., the chamber will hold a roll call vote.

AROUND THE HILL -- Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) will hold a photo/video availability with newly elected GOP senators at 9:15 a.m. in S-230.

The Senate Republican Conference will hold a meeting to elect leaders for the 116th Congress at 9:30 a.m. in the Old Senate Chamber.

Reps. Randy Hultgren (R-Ill.) and Jim McGovern (D-Mass.) will hold a hearing on reducing the risk of mass atrocities at 10 a.m. in 2200 Rayburn.

The House Administration Committee will hold a photo opportunity for the members-elect of the 116th Congress at 10:30 a.m. on the East Front Plaza of the Capitol.
